item.name: 1066, Tears To Many Mothers
item.comment: Tentative rating given for proto-type edition played with designer - may not be same as final version. Very strong, asymmetrical race/fight game. Will be backing this on Kickstarter - though would like to see a Bayeaux Tapestry art edition!

This is the big one. After first opening the box, it is initially quite daunting to approach. The rulebook (unsurprisingly) is like nothing else, and for all its faults (some minor translation issues being the chief amongst them) the Book of Worlds is a staggering accomplishment in itself. Recommendation - do just read the rules for 123 and play that. Then pick whichever game is going to be played next, maybe set up the board (before anybody else shows up) and play through a turn. The rules seem to fall into place easier when the right components are in front of you. I'm thinking that after a half dozen games of different modules, reading the individual rulesets might be less of a challenge, and just throwing together a game to play with a group there and then be much more feasible.
At the time of writing I am in the first tentative steps of exploring 504. That this is a game that really does have such vast scope for exploration of its potential forms is one of the most exciting things about it - leading this to being the first ever game that I had to buy on release, sight unseen.
It is undoubtedly a work of genius - are the games going to be great? I really couldn't say, and don't yet care. I've played three games so far (123, 456 and 816) - enjoyed them, would play any of them again, but am eager to explore further. I don't know whether I am going to want to keep trying new combinations, or whether I'll find that there are certain worlds that I want to keep returning to. It's going to be interesting to find out!

item.name: 7 Wonders
item.comment:
Definitely a very enjoyable game, with the drafting element providing another new combination of old mechanics to make a building game enjoyableSpeed of play is obviously a big plus. For some reason, I don't feel particularly drawn to try to add this to my collection.
[Edit] Bought with Amazon credit, which helped bring the price to a respectable level (still £17 with sleeves, ow), as this is one of my wife's favourite games. We played a bit 2 player - which is decent, just high risk of burnout due to most cards getting seen every game. Definitely best with 3 or 4 owing to the strategic element of planning what to gamble on coming back into your hand.
It has gone up in my estimation owing to the fact that I TOTALLY ROCK AT THIS GAME, which clearly demonstrates that ist is a game that rewards sheer puissance and good breeding.

item.name: Abalone
item.comment: Solid two player abstract. Easy enough for pretty much anyone to pick up, very enjoyable tactile quanlity as the balls click into place, as the actress said to the vicar, etc.

item.name: Above and Below
item.comment: I have no idea if this is something that I'd enjoy playing a lot, but the inclusion of the book of paragraphs was a welcome change to an action-optimising economic game. Nice production, and fun.

item.name: Ad Astra
item.comment: Good, and I think I prefer it to Settlers, but it just wasn't going to see the plays. Traded for Space Alert, which is even less likely to see play, but which I could not resist.

item.name: Addiction
item.comment: This is an OK word game, of the many thousand dice-based word games. Not better than Boggle, however.

item.name: Advanced Heroquest
item.comment: Battle against the Rat Men! You can tell there wasn't a lot of competition when this came out. Slightly more point to it if you already have a substantial collection of monster miniatures. The tables for generating solo dungeons in the old AD&D DM's guide are better than this flimsy product. Comes complete with swinging doors, though! And a bunch of identical rat men! What larks, Pip! Edit : my original ratings of 2 then 3 seem a bit harsh. The quality of the tiles is pretty good, and as an expansion for Heroquest it is probably pretty useful. Can't help but compare the rule set to things like the solo dungeoneering tables printed in an issue of Warlock magazine, which I'm pretty sure had more meat to them than the effort made for AHQ Edit again (April 2011): And having had another look at the rules, having picked up a copy from a charity shop, I have to concede that there is something interesting about how the ruleset approach dungeon-crawling as a boardgame - eg the idea that the GM has to follow a set of rules and randomly generate a dungeon during play. Is this what WHQ refined? The tiles are also well-suited to this purpose. May try playing some time.

item.name: Age of Conan: The Strategy Board Game
item.comment: I like this, but after one two and one four player game, still find it a bit clunky; interaction is limited by the game design, poor choices aren't punished enough (too many opportunities to catch up). The end game stages and crowning of Conan are interesting, and the tension of the 'micro-games' are enjoyable, but so far for me, the whole feels a bit laborious.

item.name: Age of Empires III: The Age of Discovery
item.comment: Seems to have a good level of appeal to players of either a euro or theme game disposition. Tense, involving, gameplay moves at a steady pace. Many paths to victory, and players must react to the strategies of everybody else at the table. All round a good, solid game.

item.name: Age of Industry
item.comment: Enjoyable, the mileage that different maps and rules variations can give the game are compelling - would I always prefer to play Brass? So far, yes.

item.name: Agricola
item.comment:
I never really get why so many people are down on farming as a theme - did they not have toy tractors and an assortment of plastic animals in different scales as a kid? Playing with little wooden sheep and cows appeals to something on a very fundamental level. With the different modes of play (which can cover the range from light, family fun to an intense strategic & tactical challenge) and the vast number of optional decks of cards, there is a ridiculous amount of game in this box.
At somewhere over a hundred plays, I'm not by any means burned out on the game, but enjoy it as an occasional indulgence rather than a weekly entertainment. That's a decent amount of play for one game.

item.name: Agricola: All Creatures Big and Small
item.comment: Trimmed down Agricola, why not? Generally, because I'd just as soon play a 2p game of Gric - so portability is the main draw: something to pack for a short holiday.

item.name: Albion
item.comment: (Bought as part of the great Works £7.99 sale of 2011). 2-player: The components are very nice, I like the implementation of theme through the mechanics which make sense to me. But overall, it seems to be missing something. At the moment it plays like Settlers without random resource collection (much like the Roman themed iPhone settlers clone, is this a coincidence?). The bones of the game and the bits are too nice not to hope that somebody can come up with an interesting variation - maybe having different win condition (eg earning vps), more ways to directly screw with each other (legionaries being able to seize 'tributes' from the production plants) and maybe even dice added to combat.

item.name: Alchemists
item.comment: I messed up somewhere along the way during my only play, and it soured me a bit. I can see this being fun if you get things right.

item.name: Alien Frontiers
item.comment: An enjoyable game, very nicely themed and produced. Funnily enough, it seems to come down to the luck of the dice most of the time, but the game is still reasonably fun for all that. Better than Kingsburg, but not exactly a million miles above Yahtzee (which I don't particularly mean as a criticism as I also quite enjoy playing that from time to time).

item.name: Android
item.comment: Over the top FFG production values, combined with bargain basement prices mean that I would be happy for this game to sit on my shelves virtually unplayed and unlikely to be played - which is essentially the situation. I can see this going down very well with the right group of players, although the necessity to learn a bunch of odd mechanics is a necessary barrier, as according to comments here on the geek is the 'fit up a suspect' rather than 'solve a mystery' gameplay - not a problem for me personally:it seems to fit in well with the dystopian sf background, and makes for an interesting and very gamey mechanic - always useful in a board game. Edit after a proper 4 player game: Plays extremely well and fits my expectations above. For me the biggest problems were - 1) having to go through the rule book to give a rules explanation owing to not having 'revised' properly before play - with set up this took about an hour and greatly annoyed Mrs Schkff. Solution: prepare properly 2)all the flavour text being a bit messy - we opted not to go through the procedure of everybody reading out their text so it was optional for players if they wanted to read their own flavour text or not. The game manages to flow on reasonably well almost completely ignoring the text, but some sense of the story is lost a bit here. As with the rules explanation, this problem was really just down to our own approach to the game, and did not spoil play. Solution: either want to read the text, or be happy ignoring it; not a particularly big deal. 3) Mrs Schkff being impatient about how long I apparently took on my turns, whilst wanting to stop and check if she was able to play a dark card on every player after what seemed like every single move. Grr. Solution: Do not play Android with Mrs Schkff. 4) Some annoying vagueness about how to use the day marker track, and a number of questions about the conspiracy board. Solution: read the rules properly. All these problems aside, this was an intense and for three of us very enjoyable game, which in the end could have gone either way - this with a great variety in the strategy and approaches each player took. The whole evidence planting mechanic is pure genius, far more interesting than any deduction game could possibly be.

item.name: Android: Netrunner
item.comment:
Game play is absolutely superb - if you have the right gaming partner and don't care about the outside world, then you could get a hell of a lot of play out of the core set alone. There's much to be learned about playing this game well, and it relies on more fundamental gaming skills than just knowledge of cards - ie, bluffing, reading intent, managing risk and putting your neck out, boldness and invention. I really like it.
Can't keep up with the sale model, though. It's really great that the entire game is affordable if that's your gaming focus, but it's not so great if your budget is limited, though that is what it is. There's nothing stopping a deck without Clone Chips or Jackson Howard or currents or whatever going up against a netdeck tricked out with every flash card going and still scoring a win - or even just enjoying a good game (though getting pummelled)...
If you live in an urban area where there are a lot of Netrunner players meeting up regularly for games, you are depriving yourself of a delicious addiction if you don't give it a try. It is a game that demands real commitment, though - not so much because you have to stay up to date to stay competitive (though you largely do), but because it is that good of a game in itself. Which is no bad thing.

item.name: Antike
item.comment: I didn't really warm to this. I did as badly as on my first games of Imperial and Imperial 2030, but I didn't experience that desire to have another go to try and get it right. Maybe just because it is a similar game, and I can only take so much hammering. Wouldn't turn down a game, though.

item.name: Antike Duellum
item.comment:
Not entirely sure what to make of game play yet. I enjoy Antike as a multi-player, and I love Hamburgum both multi and two player, think I would enjoy Imperial 2030 2 player. So I like Antike Duellum, but will need to play more to know whether it will really hold out for me.
What I can say is that the game is superb value for money bits-wise - double-sided map, lots of nice wooden pieces, small box, pleasing art and graphic design - all for under £20: bargain. But will I always end up playing some other 2-player? Not yet decided.

item.name: Arkham Horror
item.comment:
Yet to play. Want to like this, although I am dubious about 'flavour text' in games - if I want to enjoy bad writing I'll read Lovecraft, who does it best.
After 1 play : Ok, the rule book deserves all the criticism, but this is no Magic Realm. Gameplay is reasonably smooth, and I have to say, so far, I am really liking it. Plus the wife actually enjoyed it a lot more than our previous co-op experience (Lord of the Rings and Pandemic), in spite of the fact that it took us nearly 4 hours to play.
Flavour text seems snappier than in Runebound, the theme is wonderfully worked. Shame about the Ghoul illustration (which is even accompanied by a description of the 'canine' features) - that ain't no Lovecraftian Ghoul, I must mewl.
Considerably exceeded expectations.
2015 edit:I eventually sold all my Arkham stuff - it never got played, and took up too much space. I bought Elder Signs as a replacement. Something about the comparative size and simplicity appealed to me. If space and money weren't an issue, though, Arkham might have stayed.

item.name: Ascension: Deckbuilding Game
item.comment:
Ugh. I really wonder what it is I am missing here. This just isn't a game! These early games that 'solved' the problem of theme-lack in Dominion are a travesty. Maybe it gets better with expansions?
2015 Edit: I do quite enjoy the phone version from time-to-time, however. My earlier "isn't a game" verdict should be "isn't a game that has much appeal for me". And the Dominion 'solvers' aren't a travesty - but I still don't think any beat the original for genuine, solid game play. I wouldn't play Ascension on the phone if I had an equally well-implemented Dominion app. Star Realms gets what this does right, I reckon. BTW, played this online a bit and got fairly regularly beat, so I guess that there must be something more than luck of the draw/buy the best card involved! Rating upped to a 5

item.name: Asteroyds
item.comment: Moving the asteroids gets a bit fiddly and through the game they seem to tend to drift into the corners and become less relevant, but I enjoyed this as a novel twist on the fast, filler race game category. This was available widely in the UK discounted at the Works, and well worth picking up for £5-£10.

item.name: At the Gates of Loyang
item.comment: Quite satisfying as a two player. What I like over Agricola is the lack of fuss. As a multi-player, I prefer Bohnanza, and for lighter Uwe board games, probably prefer Merkator - but it's a decent un.

item.name: Augustus
item.comment: Roman bingo. I liked it - good end-of-the-night game, I thought.

item.name: Automobile
item.comment: I really enjoy the theme and mechanics of factory production. I'm sure it would bore me to tears if I was paid to do this kind of thing, but pit it in a game and I am thrilled to the core of my being. Help!

item.name: Ave Caesar
item.comment: Very entertaining race game with five or six players, nice pieces and board. Don't think I've seen anyone fail to enjoy this. (Edit: I think I may now have seen a few people resignedly tolerate this, which comes close to failing to enjoy) Especially entertaining when somebody in the lead finds themselves stuck at the finish line with a hand of sixes, and one by one, all the other players pass them: priceless.

item.name: Axis & Allies
item.comment: Wish I'd played this as a kid, because I don't think I'll get many chances now.

item.name: Backgammon
item.comment:
Games like Backgammon and Chess that are an everyday feature of life in certain cultures, and that have been so for many centuries, have an enormous appeal. Do the differences between chess and backgammon say anything about the cultures and personalities that prefer them? It's curious how backgammon usually comes in the form of a case, which implies mobility; there is a luxuriousness in the manufacture of backgammon sets rather than the sometimes ascetic quality found even with an expensive chess set (ignoring the novelty display sets of course) - and yet backgammon is the easier game to play where pebbles and sand are the only materials to hand.
The most fundamental difference between the two games, of course, is that with the combination of luck and calculable probabilities, backgammon is a game about betting, if not the game about betting (where it trumps poker, as there is a playable game even without stakes on the table).
I find something more satisfying about teaching people how to play classic games than I do any modern euro; I think that this is a combination of the simplicity and elegance that is a fundamental concept behind any game that has survived as a classic (I include chess in this definition, but obviously backgammon is simpler and easier to teach), with the cultural weight and value that such games have. Unfortunately, so far your euro game only has a cultural weight and significance to nerds and geeks: hence this (fine fine!) website, and the relatively low ranking of the classics thereon.

item.name: Batavia
item.comment: Rating might go up if I get more chances to play. The (irrelevant) theme of East Indies trading appeals to me, as do the nice wooden bits, and the the auction, plus the opportunities to sting people by triggering a pirate attack. But I'm not yet convinced whether the whole is even equal to the sum of its parts.

item.name: The Battle for Hill 218
item.comment: Didn't take to this, though was tired when I played it - if I played it a lot with the same person, I could see that I might enjoy it more.

item.name: Battlecars
item.comment: Still applaudable for it's simple but engaging play; the damage counters are still a pain in the neck though, too.

item.name: Battlegame Book 3: Galactic War
item.comment: Loved this book! I bought a copy in the Puffin Book Club, some time in the early 1980s (I think), and played these games to death - my first experience of war-gaming, indeed of anything beyond Monopoly and Cluedo. It led to an initial disappointment when I ordered Forest of Doom, my first Fighting Fantasy book, to be very confused to get a game book that didn't have a board or pieces.

item.name: Battleship Galaxies: The Saturn Offensive Game Set
item.comment: I picked this up cheap, and like it but ow! definitely missing the potential that expansions would have brought. The deck construction aspect seems well-designed - but it just ain't there without the choice of units.

item.name: BattleTech
item.comment: May play again when Schkff Jnr grows up if I haven't traded it by then. I liked filling in the little circles on the record sheets.
item.conditiontext: Well used, but everything there (from original release) - also have the Battletech RPG book

item.name: Big Boggle
item.comment: I prefer this to regular Boggle.

item.name: Bios: Megafauna
item.comment: I liked it. Interesting enough, whatever its frustrations for some as a game.

item.name: Block Mania
item.comment: A bit too fiddly
item.conditiontext: with exapansion set (both boxes, all components

item.name: Blockade
item.comment: This is an earlier incarnation of Quorridor, of course. Has the advantage of being able to play regular Quorridor and the version in this box with the same board - the only disadvantage is the ugly plastic pieces. Worth picking up from a charity shop.

item.name: Blokus
item.comment: Deeply satisfying to play, one of the best 4 player fillers. Very annoying to play vs AP - just play your frikkin tile already! It seems that it's much more difficult for some people to 'see' the options, which I personally find very intuitive. Speed play!

item.name: Blokus Duo
item.comment: Enjoyable and fast as a 2 player abstract. Games are 'played out' much quicker than the full game, but speed of play is one of the attractions. If you want a meatier game, go for one of the big brothers with 2 colours apiece. Would prefer an edition with a built-in, plastic carrying case.

item.name: Blokus Trigon
item.comment: I really like Blokus, and at first this version seems less satisfying, as it's much harder to block and get a grip on. But the more I play, the more I feel I get it. Add the scalability - thi plays excellently (though differently) with 2, 3, or 4 - and the fact that you can make MUCH PRETTIER PATTERNS WITH TRIANGLES, leads to the inevitable conclusion : Blokus Trigon is the one version of Blokus that you must own! (Edit April 2011): My comment above is no doubt weighted by the fact that this is the version of Blokus I have stumbled across cheap to buy. It has all the merits I have listed, but I think that there is an indefinable something to Blokus Classic - or even a definable something, which is to say that it is easier to block and to visualise moves.

item.name: Blue vs. Gray
item.comment: Very much hope to get to play this against a live opponent some day, but enjoyable to play solo; great simulation of the big picture of the battles of the American Civil War. Very frustrating when Sherman leads a successful assault on Richmond only to be 'fired', but I guess that must have been the dirty work of some Copperheads in Washington...

item.name: Boggle
item.comment: Apart from being an enjoyable word game, it has an egg timer and you get to rattle a box full of letter dice then shake them into the grid.

item.name: Bohnanza
item.comment: Very enjoyable set -collecting game, with deceptively devious "gifting" mechanic.

item.name: Brass
item.comment:
The theme is an instant winner for me. Maybe an interest in the industrial revolution and North West England helps. Numerous strategies for success, but a player must be flexible depending on what cards they are dealt, and upon what strategies their oponents are pursuing. Really, really like this game. Wallace's best ever?
The two player variant is worthwhle, and even though there are no shortage of games to play for 2, I don't think there is much competition for a serious economic game.
4 player is clearly where this game is best - the competition is insane, and there is something really delightful about the struggle to find an economic niche. But three player is solid too, altho I think there may be more risk of a player's lead to snowball if allowed to dominate an industry - so don't let em.
If playing this with me, be prepared to get fed up at my shaking my head and saying "I really, really love this game" periodically.

item.name: A Brief History of the World
item.comment:
Whatever this loses from the original has to be worth it for the increased playability. Kind of funny how it is 'brief' still requiring a good 3 hours to play.
Anyhow, components are really nice, and the combat rules are definitely an improvement.

item.name: Buccaneer
item.comment: Think I have yet to play this game with the right group. It needs fast play and an intuitive understanding of what is going on - but more than that, the players need to enjoy it, which appears to be a sticking point with people I've suggested it to. Very nice components. May be too random.

item.name: The Bucket King
item.comment: Great fun - smack talking is absolutely essential. Very popular with our group, have played with people who take it more seriously - not as much fun. For a quicker (and more portable) game in this vein, try Straw.

item.name: Bull in a China Shop
item.comment: I like - but it is indeed a game where it's hard to be sure you have any real control over your victory chances. Fun, though, and beautifully produced to boot.

item.name: Byzantium
item.comment: I would definitely play this again. The idea and implementation of playing both sides in a conflict is genius; I think on the whole that this is definitely one of Wallace's more under-rated games.

item.name: Caesar & Cleopatra
item.comment: There's nothing wrong with this per se, but half-hour long two-player card games aren't exactly an area of my game collection that is in need of more options. Nothing particularly compelling about this to make it worth getting over any of the many rivals, unlress the theme particularly appeals (or the possibility to offend somebody sensitive to such words because there are 'orgy' cards...)

item.name: Campus
item.comment: Actually quite an enjoyable little solo bingo-style game.

item.name: Car Wars
item.comment: I adored Car Wars as a teen. I think I would happily give it a go again.
item.conditiontext: This trade item represents an as yet unsorted stack of early car wars sets (incl truckstop, sunday drivers, duel track) and ADQs. all much used

item.name: Carcassonne
item.comment:
Best played on a small table. Wife and I immediately took to this in a very cut throat style of play, couldn't imagine playing it any other way.
Edit: Also, at age 3, my son really enjoys playing this (by just taking turns to place tiles, not bothering with meeples and scoring).

item.name: Carcassonne: The Castle
item.comment:
Far more visually appealing than vanilla - how can you not love the little dudes riding pigs? - I also love the way that it encourages much more logical building, somewhat counter-intuitively in spite of the less restricted spacing rules. Scoring system has crazy randomness, which evens the playing field in a way that demand fun.
I prefer playing Carc on a limited space table anyway, so the castle actually seems somewhat spacious.
Copy I have played had some sub-standard production -eg, peeling tiles, and very poor fit on the 'jigsaw' pieces.

item.name: Carrom
item.comment:
Acquired a decent quality 20" board and have immediately fallen in love with this game. It's like pool that you can 1) carry with you to the pub, 2) Doesn't cost £1 - £2 per game, 3) plays doubles really well, and 4) you don't have to get up off your arse to take a shot! What's not to love?
Would like to play a full size board some day, am happy with kids size until I can actually make a shot more than 1 time in 10.

item.name: Cartagena
item.comment:
Simple, yet very satisfying abstract chase game. Open card variant allows plenty of potential for brain-burning AP, should you go in for that kind of thing.
Picked this up in a sale at Forbidden Planet for £2.99. Nice!
Edit : (after about 9 months) Remains a big favourite for me and the missus. Still one of the most satisfying games for 2 players in our collection. Doesn't quite seem to have the same fun factor as other acquisitions (Portobello Market, Downfall of Pompeii) when broken out as a 'gateway' game, but still a reliable choice.
Also, I often manage to beat my wife, which is becoming a rarity of anything we play. Double plus.
item.conditiontext: Very good condition (so far) - not sure what I'd trade for as it fits a very important 2p niche, but am open to offers.

item.name: The Castles of Burgundy
item.comment: I'm sure I'll get to play this more in the years to come, as it seems assured of classic status. I find the small pieces and colour choices a bit of an annoyance. The old 'multi-player solitaire criticism' applies well here - but that is often exactly the kind of game I want to play. Although they've had a real renaissance in the last few years, Feld deserves kudos for his continued use of the humble dice. Certainly they should ensure continued replayability with this delicious vp-cruncher game.

item.name: Catan Card Game
item.comment: Good value for what's included, which is a reasonably engaging 2 player variant on the Settlers theme. What is truly amazing is the amount of space this game can take up - far more than even 6 player Catan, more in fact than War of the Ring or even Arkham plus - in fact only Sorcerer's Cave in my collection takes up more playing space...

item.name: Cave Evil
item.comment: Entertaining. I think I prefer the simpler design of Titan, to which it bears superficial resemblance. Really like the graphic design choices, though, particularly in light of how difficult they make game play. Truly evil!

item.name: Caverna: The Cave Farmers
item.comment: Enjoyed it. Think I prefer Agricola or Gric w Farmers of the Moor.

item.name: Caylus
item.comment: I can understand why people may love this game, but I have probably found it the least enjoyable of the worker-placement games I have played so far. Extremely ugly and garish board and component design, laborious play. Has merits which I may grow to appreciate if badgered into playing again, eg admittedly a continued sense of involvement. First play wasn't helped by the fact that the explainer went into great depth about the mechanics, without giving any of the 'theme' explanations of what the hell we were actually doing and whatever all the little cubes were supposed to represent. It really underlined the whole 'book-keeping' nature of the game. Plus he was hyper-competitive, talking players out of making any decision that adversely affected himself, ho-hum. On the whole I was disappointed by the game as I find the box art appealing and intruiging. Edit (Oct 2010): I finally got to play Caylus in more amenable circumstances, and enjoyed it very much. Plus I won, which helps a lot in the game appreciation stakes. Deep and involving, but possibly too long if facing competition from other games that scratch a similar itch.

item.name: Caylus Magna Carta
item.comment:
Can't help but wonder why someone would go to the trouble of reworking a board game to come up with an ever so slightly less complex version, utilising cards in a board game fashion, and encumbered by all the cubes and markers - Caylus MC certainly does not take the San Juan path of elegance in approaching its original.
However, I am glad that they did. The randomness of the shuffled building cards counters a great deal of the dryness of the original, whilst still requiring thought and strategy from the player.
Acquiring this in the Works £7.99 sale (along with the Ystari expansion box for £2.99) means that I am unlikely to bother hunting down a copy of the board game.
Edit: I am finding this a bit unsatisfactory with just 2 players. If one player goes ahead they tend to stay ahead, and there can be a considerable difference in the luck of the draw on cards. Don't think this would be anything like as much of an issue with even one more player.
I may be saying this because my wife keeps beating me, as she does with Ingenious and Roll Through the Ages.

item.name: Chainsaw Warrior
item.comment: Actually, although I lusted after this I don't think I ever played it BITD, even though my mate had a copy - which he recently passed on to me. It is worth critics remembering - this board game was made before the first-person-shooter video game genre existed beyond our fevered imaginations. It seems that there is enough in the box to cobble together something a little more interesting to play, ie with just a few decisions to make during play. The Brett Ewins art is the biggest selling point - shame it wasn't ewins on the cards though.

item.name: Chang Cheng
item.comment: Beautiful components. For some reason this one proves too complex for non-gamers, and seems to fall a little flat with gaming crowd. Nice pieces really make up for a lot, though.

item.name: Chess
item.comment:
Just wish to be clear that the relatively low rating is based on my hesitation to play, although I do go through phases of being fired up about the game. Half an hour spent reading up on basic strategy ought to open up the game for most people, and disprove the usual silly objections about it being a game that rewards memorizing sequences of opening moves. Not that people have to like chess, but when BGGers call the game 'broken,' well, they sound a little bit ridiculous.
First game my wife and I played together. Mrs Schkff comes from one of those cultures where chess is routinely played in school and everybody knows how to play.
Edit : am upping my rating, as there's no way I'd turn down a game or three, and am happy being beaten by someone who can really play, or else coaching someone in the basics. Chess is fun!
Theme somewhat pasted on, though, it has to be admitted. And what self-respecting king would marry a pawn, just because it made its way across a battlefield? Tsk.
Edit again 2014: Rating dropped a point again - am just not feeling the Chess love at the moment. Thjis may change as the kids get old enough to learn.

item.name: Chicago Express
item.comment: Enjoyed this a lot. The production is very nice. Can't decide whether I prefer this or Steel Driver, which is more elegant as a game, but less engaging for theme. The little share certificates in CE may be the deciding factor. I am shallow. Edit (Oct 2010): I think I do prefer Steel Driver, really, but am glad that Wabash Cannonball is now on the iPhone. And CE is often temptingly cheap, so this may eventually see its way into my game collection.

item.name: Chronology
item.comment: It doesn't quite deserve to be, because luck of the draw is everything, but this is a very enjoyable filler, a great way to end a gaming night (so ender rather than filler I suppose) and I imagine like Wits and Wagers in that it allows know it alls a chance to show off (something I consider very important) whilst not actually guaranteeing them a win.

item.name: Churchill
item.comment: Only played the intro game of 3 conferences. I think I'd like this more after playing the full game - in the shorter scenario, the victory conditions kind of rapidly swung out of control of the players, and of course you don't get the narrative of pushing through DDay and so on. Really interesting to play something simulating this level of command; brought to mind Wallace's "God's Playground" (3p competitive but working against common enemies).

item.name: Circular Chess
item.comment: Every person who wanted to like chess but hated being beaten by better players should try this. I don't think the opening book can possibly apply. Certainly beefs up rooks and queens by another few factors - which may not be what chess needs, but is fun. Pow!

item.name: Cirondo
item.comment: It's not as fun as Circular Chess. There may be more strategy to it, but I dunno. Nice heavy pieces though.

item.name: Citadels
item.comment: Mostly played two player with Mrs Schkff, who loves it provided she wins. I sympathise with people who hate this game, as I would usually play something else. Really does scale very well from 2 to 7. The person who hates playing the most always gets assassinated on the first round, and then sulks for the remainder of the game. Tiresome in large groups if peole are stricken with AP - just choose the f*ing architect and pass the deck!

item.name: La Città
item.comment: Bought in The Works clearance sale. I liked it, but can't see getting people to play a euro of this vintage now when there are so many other options - bit long and doesn't stand out enough.

item.name: The City
item.comment: Liked this a lot - super fast, fairly light tableau building game.

item.name: Civilization
item.comment: Wish to play more. Very elegant system, just requires a group who can make a social event of the game.
item.conditiontext: First Edition (Hartland Trefoil), all in pretty good nick, excepting some of the 1 value cards are very worn, and the box is quite dented and aged. Board and other cards, AST track, counters, all practically as new.

item.name: Clans
item.comment: Superb game. Where's the love, Geeks?

item.name: Clash of Cultures
item.comment: I wanted to like this more than I did, but I certainly didn't dislike it. I feel that the balance of the game makes it a real challenge to do anything other than get in the arms race. But it has a lot of really nice features, and of course great over-the-top Z-man production - slightly let down as ever by the less than first rate actual component quality. I think I would generally prefer to play either TTA or just a straight up multi player war game. Or Eclipse, which I think gets the balance better in spite of its own flaws.

item.name: Claustrophobia
item.comment: Splendid game, scoring extremely highly for playability, ease of set-up, variety, production, and value for money. Other games are going to be judged by the standards of this one for years to come. I think if it had passed the Vasel test this would be in the BGG top ten already. The sheer tactile pleasure of holding the solidly constructed, weighty box is almost disturbing... Thematic Game of the Year and 2 player Game of the Year 2010, without hesitation. The one minor quibble is problems distinguishing the Condemned minis and having to use a generic demon - Asmodee must rectify this by producing a booster pack of alternate figures, including the other demons and figures armed with the blundebus, shield etc, or I will be forced to downgrade this to a 1 out of spite. [Edit:] That's a joke about the spite-rating, but I am a bit surprised that alternative miniature packs weren't marketed for this game seeing as the game is based on a line of miniatures. I'm too lazy to find proxies.
item.conditiontext: Played a number of times, cards all sleeved and general condition very good - some damage to the box including a split down one side however.
item.wantpartslist: Want parts as yet unmade - ie, Blade w. Blunderbus, Brute w shield, and all those other demons. And I want them now!

item.name: Cleopatra en het genootschap van de architecten
item.originalname: Cleopatra and the Society of Architects
item.comment: So far only played 2 player with the wife (who loves this game). An entertaining game for an hour of play, luck of the draw can be a bit tiresome in a 2 player game, but is even so fun.

item.name: Coda
item.comment: At the time of writing every single charity shop in Penrith (well, almost, 5 out of 8) has a copy of "The Da Vinci Code Game". This is a very decent two player deduction filler game.

item.name: Codenames
item.comment: Neat game: though its broad appeal really surprises me - I would have though that more people would struggle to find the fun in this - I guess Vlaada has the magic touch, or I tend to snootily underestimate people.

item.name: Colossal Arena
item.comment: Fine game, a bit ponderous, potentially very swingy. I like it, difficult to persuade anyone else to play.

item.name: Colosseum
item.comment: Extremely enjoyable, but quite probably a game that would benefit from only being played now and then. Great bits!

item.name: Combat Commander: Europe
item.comment: After 3 plays, I think I am firmly in the camp of people who really enjoy this game and trying to manage the chaos. I like games that tell stories and that surprise me. I particularly enjoy the challenge of trying to pull off a bigger strategy whilst having to respond tactically to an ever changing and confounding situation.

item.name: Confucius
item.comment: One play so far. Confusing to play out of the box without anyone having played it before (same could be said of plenty of decent games), and some passages of the rules add to this by being a bit headachey; but eventually it clicked. Quite a delightful game, really. Is the scoring range too small, and the results of the voting for government office too swingy? Perhaps, but there appears to be a lot of potential here for deep and devious play, leavened by luck, that draw me to playing again.

item.name: Cosmic Encounter
item.comment:
I remember struggling and failing to understand this when it (GW edition) came out, I guess when I was 13. But I was really drawn to it, and wanted to like it.
Picked up a copy in trade a while back, finally got to play the FFG edition, on learning that far from being better with more, 3 is a perfectly acceptable number to play with.
The game has proven to be everything I wanted it to be; intensely enjoyable. The anticipation before a game, wondering what combo the powers will provide this time (and will they - can I force them to? - favour me?) is sublime.
Love both versions - altho Flares are neat, there's something just right in the GW ed balance.

item.name: Cosmic Encounter
item.comment: Can't knock the new edition for all the stuff available, but I'm happy with my old Games Workshop edition.

item.name: Coup
item.comment: This was fun. Instinctively,I prefer it to Love Letter, which I do like anyway. Verily, we are in a golden age for light back-stabby small deck fast playing card games, and happily so.

item.name: Coup: Rebellion G54
item.comment: This is a fantastic game - Coup still has it place, but Guatemala puts the game up about ten notches. Love the art and theme of the original edition, the bland Resistance theming saddens me, though I'd still play it.

item.name: Cribbage
item.comment: Recently learned off of an Ipod app, and have now acquired a nice board and pegs. I am loving the Cribbage, very much. Two for his heels!

item.name: Crokinole
item.comment: Nice if you can get hold of a decent board. There must be hundreds of old flicking games, but I think that this one has survived on its merits. Carrom is "better", of course (and cheaper), especially for four, but this is quicker and lighter to play - less demoralizing if like me you are hopelessly inept.

item.name: Cuba
item.comment:
This is probably not a game that I would have ended up buying were it not in the famous £7.99 sale at The Works. To date I have only played it two player - for which it is absolutely essential to use one of the variants for dealing with the ships, something I find a little annoying design-wise (that the game requires some tinkering to scale for fewer players, and that this didn't seem to be picked up on in play testing.)
But this is nonetheless an enjoyable and challenging game, with an interesting range of strategies for players to explore (all of which must, however, be undertaken with the understanding that this is a game which very quickly reaches its end stages).
It feels quite different from Puerto Rico to play, in spite of superficial similarities.

item.name: Cube Quest
item.comment: Extremely entertaining, fast dexterity (flicking) game, with surprising scope for interesting strategic and tactical play. Charming box art, too. [Edit: The previous refer to the Kingbrick edition, but the Cube Quest version looks decent too. Sadly the art is a little less endearingly cheesy.]

item.name: Dead of Winter: A Crossroads Game
item.comment:
Entertaining. For me, the balance of co-op to hidden objectives is about right. Seem to be a lot of flaky cards, which can be forgiven, but might lead to problems depending on how a group play. Some objectives far easier to achieve than others, though that's somewhat of a minor quibble - I like that exact balance wasn't considered necessary in the design, it should be possible to enjoy this without it.
Overall, play experience can be much greater than the sum of the parts. The atmosphere generated in the game really fits the setting.

item.name: Descent: Journeys in the Dark (Second Edition)
item.comment:
I own D1e but still haven't played it - traded it a while ago but had limited interest off other players to try it. Playing 2e has rekindled my interest in trying out 1st.
Things I like - the sculpts are vastly superior on the minis and the scales seem in better proportion - too many ginormous models in 1e for my taste. Art again is a vast improvement - the character art in particular. Also, general aesthetics, layout, etc are all several notches up. And minimal need to refer to rules is commnedable. Play itself: So as stated, I haven't experienced the notorious 5 hour drudgery of 1e's kill cycle, although I suspect I would get a kick out of it.
The colour to the scenarios is a lot of fun, but I wonder if they have much replayability. Most are over very quickly, and tend to have odds stacked to one side or the other, with this being offset by only minimal impact of winning or losing. Bizarrely the most significant encounters can be the random road encounters (my crew took a bigger haul of items from one of these cards than across two scenarios). But I do like the pace of progression - which is to say tantalisingly slow. It's the progression experience of an RPG campaign condensed across a couple of weeks rather than a couple of years or (in D1e's case) a couple of hours. Playing the OL seems inherently less interesting, with fewer choices and decisions than 1e gave.
On the whole, 2e seems to be a really good intro to 1e - but until I actually experience 1e for myself I should avoid drawing conclusions from my experience so far. Enjoyed it a lot, but it leaves me wanting more. Will my 1st edition plus the cards from the expansions (thanks to the secondary market caused by 2e on 1e cannibalization) and Road to Legend satisfy that craving? Time will tell...

item.name: Discworld: Ankh-Morpork
item.comment: First Impressions: I don't really know why I preordered this except that I am pretty much a Wallace fanboy, and did enjoy the first few Discworld novels as a teenager. I am wary that my opinion may change, but I have certainly enjoyed the game so far after 4 2player games against Mrs Schkff. The board is a lot more important to the game than the one in London (to take another Wallace card game themed on a chaotic and malodorous metropolis as an example), the randomness is fun, and balanced by the fact that the cards only come in a small number of different types. Also, the trouble mechanic is classic Wallace - at first seems odd, then proves simple, thematic and gamey. The system wouldn't accept a 7a rating, and 9 seems a bit high just yet (might get there though) so for now this is a safe 7. [Edit after first 4 player game]: People who think that Vimes always wins are bufoons. Sorry, but this is true. [Edit after reading Guards! Guards! for the first time] I can't get over how true to the spirit of Pratchett's writing this game is. Love it.

item.name: Diversion
item.comment: Draughts, with the option to move pieces of board as well as playing pieces. Superb concept, but gameplay doesn't quite live up to the premise, as either owing to flakiness of rules or some fundamental flaw in concept, draws have to be deliberately avoided. Nice bits though!

item.name: Dixit
item.comment: I liked this a lot. Great game, great art.

item.name: Doctor Who: The Card Game
item.comment:
I thought this was fun. There is a touch of the blands about it, but it's good to have another choice for take-thatism. Nice compnents, seems to be good value. Somehow the rhythm of the game felt like Cosmic Encounter to me, for reasons that I haven't bothered to properly analysed. With that in mind, I would alwatys prefer to play CE, but might consider owning this in order to have a more portable game in that ilk.
Full disclosure: I am not all that arsed about any post-Tom Baker Doctor Who, but think the recent attempts have been worthwhile, and some of the episodes (well, Blink anyway) have even actually been good.

item.name: Dominant Species
item.comment: A very solid game, with the somewhat admirable yet curious feature of being almost dangerously long for modern board gaming. I like the aesthetic and the cover art, on the whole in this category (of sneaky/combative area majority scoring games) I think I prefer Age of Empires III (more fun) and Confucious (more interesting). Does kind of surprise me how highly rated it is here on BGG, which I would choose to take as a positive sign that long, serious games are by no means out of fashion. Stiff competition, I would have thought though, from faster playing weighty games, such as Hansa Teutonica.

item.name: Dominion
item.comment: 2014 Edit: Still haven't played another deck-builder that manages to quite get it right mechanically to the extent that Dominion does. But I rarely get it to the table anymore. Rating settles to a modest 8.

item.name: Dominoes
item.comment:
Mostly playing Chicken Foot, which I larned off of the Internet and enjoy.
Playing in dominoe drives at the village hall was a highlight of the year as a kid. Have moved back to more rural location and am pleased to see from the local papers that domino drives are still a big part of village life. Am tempted to go to one some time and try and rock their world with Chicken Foot ( because standard British dominoes is a pretty lame game by comparison ).

item.name: The Downfall of Pompeii
item.comment: This is a very silly game which is extremely enjoyable. As I always get picked on, my rating has slid a little. No game collection could possibly be complete without it, a big hit with neophyte gamers - who can resist the joy of dropping coloured cubes into the hungry maw of Vesuvius?

item.name: Dreadfleet
item.comment:
Couldn't resist the lure of this. For Space Hulk I was happy to buy the game sans models and use earlier marines and stealers; in this case, I had to have the whole thing. Once painted, will I ever get a chance to play it? Feasibly not, but I hope so.
Biggest pull was the lavish John Blanche art and general Blanchesque aesthetic, surely some of his best GW work? Admittedly, I haven't seen much GW stuff since the late 80s, so maybe I've missed some gems.
Edit: Finished, the game looks absolutely as ravishing as photos lead one to expect. This really bears the hallmarks of a labour of love for someone or ones at GW. I have played a few games. The game itself is OK, sthe mechanism for event cards/wind I found a bit of an annoyance. Playing with the ships though is just great, and the overall gameplay experience is situationally sublime (but mostly I would certainly just prefer to play something better).
(NB rated as a model kit this would be an unhesitating 10)

item.name: Duel of Ages II
item.comment: Hats off to this - it's clearly a labour of love. Every collection should have at least one kitchen-sink type game design like Dual of Ages.

item.name: Dungeon Raiders
item.comment: Very nice graphics and art. A fun game. At any given time your seating may determine whether you can actually make a meaningful choice or not - there's a lot of working out what the next players can/must play; but it is quick and entertaining. There are similar games mechanics-wise that may be better play-wise, but the theme is very nicely worked in and overall production a treat.

item.name: Dungeon Roll
item.comment: Fun enough. I would probably really grow to like this.

item.name: Dungeon Twister
item.comment: I very much enjoyed the few plays I have had, but Mrs S is dead set against this.

item.name: Dungeon!
item.comment:
I played New Dungeon! a lot in my mid teens, alongside Dungeonquest, Sorcerer's Cave, Talisman, and actual AD&D. Altho this was the simplest and least intrinsically interesting of the bunch, I found that I usually enjoyed it, as fast brainless fun.
Bought the new edition and it has gone down well with my 2 and 4 year olds. For me the plusses are much improved art and the compactness - and needless to say costing £12 delivered! Well-worth getting if you have kids who you want to grow up into D&D nerds. Dubious merit otherwise.

item.name: DungeonQuest
item.comment: Fun, probably especially because of its near impossibility. I have this with the Catacombs expansion, and am increasingly of the opinion that it is better without (although the amulets are a nice addition). One deeply annoying feature is having to continually refer to the various Ryle books to find out the effect of a card - only to learn that it's "Take 1d12 - armour damage" - why couldn't they include this text on the cards. Keep meaning to take some fineline coloured markers to my cards sometime to rectify this.
item.conditiontext: condition fair to good, a number of pieces missing

item.name: Dungeons & Dragons: Castle Ravenloft Board Game
item.comment: A modern classic - the monster AI was a ground-breaking innovation, much imitated. The game is fast, fun, and beautifully made. The minis are exceptional quality and value. Later iterations implemented a lot of good ideas, but certainly of the first three games I found this the most fun to play - possibly because it is tough, certainly I found the scenarios to be most interesting. The encounters are deadly, so the game can be very challenging to beat - but some combinations of characters are much stronger than others (include the wizard in your party if you want a challenge, and don't have the cleric in play - cleric+fighter is a pretty tough team). I play it more either solo or with kids than with other adults, but have really enjoyed all my plays so far.

item.name: Dungeons & Dragons: The Fantasy Adventure Board Game
item.comment: 2010: Liking the look of this, will eventually get round to painting the figures, although they are really good as they are. Hope to play it with the kids one day, this looks like it may well be an improvement on Heroquest, let alone its successor. The failure of a US release seems inexplicable, but perhaps that itself paved the way for Ravenloft, so all is good. 2014 Edit after a few plays with the kids (ages 6,4 and 3) - fantastic game for this kind of thing. The complexity level is just right. Still not painted the figures - I am enjoying the glossy, garish colours.

item.name: Dungeons & Dragons: The Legend of Drizzt Board Game
item.comment:
Legend of Drizzt (for my money, and after one play) improves on some areas where people have found flaws in Ravenloft's design. The encounter cards are less arbitrary and take-thatish, feel more integrated to the board: for example, there are cards that trigger damage from specific tiles (those marked with lava vents) which definitely works better than the entirely random events in Ravenloft. Although the game order is still the same, there are now heroes with powers that allow them to avoid or lessen the effect of a new monster's first strike. As a result, heroes are much, much tougher than in Ravenloft - to make up somewhat for this (but not entirely, the game is definitely easier now), there are now some considerably stronger wandering monsters (eg Feral Troll).
I also like small touches such as that 'monster piles' ('shrooms in this version) are sometimes placed on the cards in places which could occasionally make them adjacent to an exploring hero, and the fact that there is a little bit more variety in monsters from the standard 3 of a kind in CR and WoA.
I guess the fact that these changes have been made acknowledges that the original design can be improved upon. I don't think the changes will be enough for people who found Ravenloft or Ashardalon completely lacking in charm, but those who have problems with the game but still find themselves inexplicably drawn to it just might be happier with the latest incarnation.
I suspect that the variety of monsters and villains of the original are more to my taste still, but time will tell on that score. I have no interest at all in either the Ravenloft or Drizzt brands, which is no hindrance for me. The silly unpronouncable names are a big plus, but why is Drzzzzzzt's pet cat named after King Arthur's wife? Odd.

item.name: Dungeons & Dragons: Wrath of Ashardalon Board Game
item.comment:
More great miniatures, interesting mix of monsters, tweaks to the tiles and the inclusion of doors handled very well. Treasure deck seems to have gone from under- to over-powered, but that's actually perfect for the purpose of combining the two decks. In general, it is impressive how well this game stands on its own AND combines and complements Ravenloft.
I like the action pose on the half-orc character, and he has some pretty neat abilities. Introduction of gold for purpose of campaigns of multiple adventures is a neat touch - not being able to level up beyond 2? Pfft, don't care. The notion that a 'campaign' would be an evening of 3 or 4 adventures back-to-back makes a lot more sense to me than something of the scope of an RPG or Road to Legend.
For those who really do want a dungeon-crawler that'll play in under an hour, and which once painted looks pretty, this franchise is going from strength to strength.
What really does surprise me is that the changes from Ravenloft seem to have been made in response to some of the criticisms/suggestions after that game - with the timeframe between releases, that is very impressive, and bodes particularly well for the next game in line.
Edit (July 2011): Shaved a point off my rating of this because, in spite of the improvements, in spite of the more classic D&D mix of monsters,I am finding that I somewhat prefer Ravenloft. One factor is the treasures in Ashardalon, which multiply through the game. The too much fiddling about with cards phenomena is worsened by the things like the Event cards that stack the deck for certain monsters - they seem a bit on the pointless side. The adventures don't feel like they have the same degree of character and appeal as Ravenloft, perhaps just being a touch clunkily and unimaginatively written. Yeah, not like Ravenloft's writing would go up against Vance or Wolfe, but there's something indefinable there that gives me a preference for the first game. Perverse, I know. I do like the doors and the horrid chambers.
Edit, October 2011: Sold/traded to acquire Dreadfleet, Waterloo and Shogun. I am still a bit in shock that I did this, as I really like the game and painting the minis was a labour of love, but faced with the need to get rid of something big to get spousal approval for Dreadfleet acquisition, I couldn't help but reflect that I just prefer Ravenloft, and as good as this is, I just don't need two D&D boardgames. I will miss it, but I think the new games will help me get over that. After all, I've had this 10 months, and only played it twice in all that time. Ashardalon Farewell!

item.name: Earth Reborn
item.comment: Initially I was pleased with this game because of the amazing amount of very nice bits. Then I eventually got around to playing it and am now grinning from ear to ear. Yes, set up is laborious, but gameplay and the narrative that evolves is highly entertaining.

item.name: Eclipse
item.comment:
Although my only play of this game so far was tedious in the extreme, I can see it being better with the right players, so I'd be reasonably happy to give it another shot. To me the games design feels a bit loose and somewhat bland, although I do quite like the graphic design and aesthetic.For epic multi player combat games, I would contrast the experience with A Game of Thrones and the Starcraft Boardgame - in both those games two players getting locked into a feud still have a chance of winning I would think (albeit one greatly reduced) - in Eclipse the cost of combat is too great, as other players can just keep building up their units and capabilities, with nothing to hold them in check.
(Edit after a second play, 3 players): The timing of conflict is important in this game, and will change depending on the actions of players. The game rewards early conflict, but I guess that Monoliths and Plasma Missiles between them provide two very effective answers to a purely military strategy - by all means, build your killer fleet, but don't expect the game to be a walkover. With 3 players was a very fun way to spend 3 hours, and my earlier experience was considerably mollified. Rating upped!

item.name: Eight-Minute Empire
item.comment:
This is a fun little package. I am a sucker for small games that come in very sturdy boxes. It's a bit too bland to hit the table too often, but a decent filler. The way board territories are drawn with ambiguous borders is a minor annoyance.
Would it have killed them to call it "15 minute empire" though?

item.name: Elder Sign
item.comment:
I really enjoyed this, although some of the rule/card combo fuzziness did begin to bug me a little. If I do ever sell my ridiculous Arkham Horror collection (ridiculous in that it is almostunplayed, I think I am mostly hanging on to it in the vague hope that my kids will love it in about 8 to 10 years time), then I'll probably get this to have some of the flavour in a neat little package. As I still have Arkham though, I find that the phone app is enough to satisfy the occassional urge to play. Nice dice, and a neat little package. Fun solo, don't know if i'd really enjoy the cooperative mode.
I sold my ridiculous Arkham collection. This fills the niche, and saves the shelf space.

item.name: Endeavor
item.comment:
Enjoy the combination of worker placement and civilization development, enjoy the theme, thumbs up. Cons include fiddly set up and, perhaps, the merest suggestion that this might be a game that has been a smidgeon over-developed, with a somewhat committee-created feel to it. Glad that they were able to include both slavery and conflict in a game themed on colonialism, it would have been a little bit silly without them.
Edit: Weird how this one dropped so quickly out of favour in gaming circles. Merits - speed of play, simplicity, variability of set-up, excellent component production. Best with 4 or 5.

item.name: Escape from Atlantis
item.comment: The very pinnacle of 1980s family game design. Still well worth getting to the table.

item.name: Euphoria: Build a Better Dystopia
item.comment:
Visually the game is very appealing, although once I got my head around how it is actually played, I was struck by very "Oh, is that it?" sentiments. It doesn't seem to do much of interest that other games don't already do, and the theme feels a bit wasted. Rubbed me the wrong way to learn that part of the board was only included as a kickstarter bonus - so the game would have been different if fewer people backed it?
The lack of mitigation of lucky rolls is the game's real flaw, though, and pretty unforgivable in design terms. Most other worker placement games I've played are better as games.
Pretty, though.

item.name: A Few Acres of Snow
item.comment: The controversy surrounding this game is instructive, and an important discussion. It seems a shame though that so many people who haven't actually played the game have written it off as broken as a result. For me, a neat game, and one of the first really great games to follow Dominion using a deck-building mechanism - more importantly the first board game to successfully fuse deck building into its play - My opinion, of course, with little regard for the dissenters. I haven't played enough to run in to the Halifax Hammer - if I did, or if I generally found deck-thinning overpowered, I'd probably follow Mantuanwar's suggested variant rather than Mr Wallace's proposed fix - but it hasn't come up, so we've just played RAW. It's a really beautiful production too, if you find any appeal in the Treefrog aesthetic, and represents its chosen period of history beautifully.

item.name: Fire in the Lake
item.comment: This just didn't work for me, though I was tired and hadn't read the rules myself, which hardly does the game justice. I don't think I enjoy this kind of thing with four players - if it's going to be an intense conflict, make it a 2player, or keep it where I can grasp it (like War of the Roses).

item.name: Firefly: Out to the Black
item.comment:
Played a play-test copy; really didn't like it, it lacked pretty much anything to make a co-op game interesting.
'Co-op' is the new 'Roll-and-move', it seems.
Edit: four 10 ratings for this?! Please get hold of a pnp copy and try it - I know nothing about the licensing hoo-ha, but as a game this just doesn't make the grade. Apologies to the designers - better luck with your next project.

item.name: Firefly: The Game
item.comment:
Solid - I like this. The components and integration of setting are up to the publisher's usual superlative standard, as is the price - I'm sure they could have asked twice as much and got it.
However, there are better games in the genre. Merchant of Venus is better as a game - flows much better and has real economic drive. Merchants and Marauders is tighter as an adventure game. But, if you love Firefly and you like adventure games, aren't too fussy about the rigour of the ruleset, then run don't walk, it's a gem.

item.name: Flash Point: Fire Rescue
item.comment: I thought this was fun, and surely a great game for the yoof.

item.name: Fleet
item.comment: Decent game in a small box. My back is always got up a bit by kickstarter exclusives - I don't like the idea that games are getting designed with bits that will taken out in the commercial edition - but I rather suspect that the simplicity of the base game benefits from lack of exclusive add ons. Very punishing, but mercifully over quickly. 2p is decent, but probably better to play something else.

item.name: For Sale
item.comment: This is such a great filler game. And I have yet to introduce it to a 'non-gamer' who hasn't loved it.

item.name: Forbidden Stars
item.comment: Yeah, this is good. I like the bits of StarCraft that have been ditched - the combat and the tech tree. But what has been added, particularly the way goals work, really makes this game a solid improvement on the earlier iteration. I might be tempted to replace StarCraft with this.

item.name: Formula D
item.comment:
Wached this and played once. Give me Pitchcar or Powerboats any day - it's too damned slow! And all the frickin rules - sheesh, what is this, Games Workshop 1985?
Very nice pieces, if I had a 12 yr old son I would happily play all the time, but the simpler race games are far greater fun for me.

item.name: Fox and Geese
item.comment: A nice traditional puzzle game, with fine foxles and geeples in this edition. So apparently it's solved: I acannot help but wonder every time I see that comment on a game whether the commentor has actually worked out /learned the solution themselves, or whether they've just heard/read that it's solved and so dismissed any further investigation. Assuming that it is indeed 'solved', I think that this nonetheless represents a nice half way mark between game and puzzle.

item.name: The Fury of Dracula
item.comment: Excellent game - works particularly well two player. I'd definitely give the FFG reprint a try, but I find the original so atmospheric: as with Warrior Knights the new boy would have a lot of expectations to live up to.
item.conditiontext: Box is much done in but components all there (last time I counted) Minis unpainted.

item.name: Fury of Dracula (third edition)
item.comment: This is the first time I've played a FFG reimplementation and thought that they got pretty much everything right, but it may still be a game that isn't really worth the time investment - though that may just be that I played 1st edition enough not to have much mileage left in this in spite of the improvements. Worth playing from time to time, better with fewer players, most fun of course for Drac.

item.name: Galaxy Defenders
item.comment: Personally, didn't care for it, but maybe with various expansions and stuff the game would be better? It felt like needlessly-fancified D&DAG to me - I'll stick with Ravenloft.

item.name: Galaxy Trucker
item.comment: Definitely forty shades of goodness in this game. Hectic fun. We played the anniversary edition with a lot thrown in, so I don't know for sure how well the base game plays unexpanded, but I can't believe that it wouldn't still be a good laugh. Long for a silly game? Maybe, but the silliness demands you give it the time it deserves.

item.name: A Game of Thrones: The Board Game (Second Edition)
item.comment:
This is a very involving game, absolutely minimal down time, and from the second turn the tree of possible moves and interactions pretty much explodes, so that it seems unlikely that any two games will be the same, and players must keep their wits about them. The mechanics seem appropriate to the theme, even though the euro-ish nature of many mechanics (the various checks and balances, and of course luckless combat) will not appeal to everybody - they should appeal to plenty, though, and for my taste really make the game, as its fascinating how uncertain things can be in spite of the lack of dice. This is by no means a unique feature to this game, but here (as compared say to War of the Roses Lancaster vs York) it somehow manages to achieve the Ameritrash feel.
I own but have not yet played 1st edition, so can't really comment on the play differences in editions, but would say that graphically the components of this edition are much more pleasing, and though I would prefer them in wood, the plastics pawns are nice enough.

item.name: Gauntlet of Fools
item.comment: I've enjoyed the couple plays of this, but on the whole if I am going to play a filler game, probably prefer something with a bit more bite. The art is great though, and it is fun for what it is.

item.name: The Generals
item.comment:
The ultimate stratego board. Did not dare to believe that this was as awsome as it looked in a border town charity shop, but my oh my, it is. Beautiful funky cream + chocolate plastic board and pieces. The battle sounds are beeptastic.
I imagine that inspite of all the advances in computer technology in the last 30 years, there hasn't been an automated 'referee' produced for any stratego edition since, which forces one to question - how far have we really advanced? The Generals - 1980 is my future!

item.name: George v Mildred Dice Game
item.comment: Picked this up owing to the bizarre incongruity of "George v Mildred: The Dice Game" - but it is a pretty decent abstract.

item.name: Gettysburg
item.comment:
So far only run through a the first day a couple times solo. I am a sucker for Wallace, wooden bits, and Gettysburg, so this was a no-brainer. Quite similar to Yankees & Rebels; the latter has a more detail on the regiments, plays slightly quicker, and I think is a bit more wargamey than this (which is inevitably tainted with Euroisms); but this has wooden soldiers! Need to play this against a human some day - soon I hope.
Edit: Eventually managed two games against Mrs S (who unfortunately refuses to play again). I like it. The first game naturally fell into historical lines, so for the second as the South I tried all kinds of gamey unhistorical moves, and won at end of first day, I think. May be most interesting for South, and for players (myself included) who enjoy a good few hours of a game that brings to mind the historical situation, without getting bogged down in detail. Would be interesting if somebody workedout some maps and house rules for other conflicts, using the same lovely wooden pieces.

item.name: Ghost Stories
item.comment:
I like the way that this plays, as a solo game. The player boards being an integral part of play, I find it easier to keep track of what's going on than with say Arkham.
Not quick to play, but involving. I will get stuck into a game, and when I am at the verge of being beat take a look at the amount of cards still left in the ghost deck, and despair.
Wouldn't personally be inclined to try it multi-player.
The gatekeeper mini-expansion mixes things up a lot, and it seems like a small additional investment (in this case $5 from BGG promo store) can add a deal of variety to the game.

item.name: Glen More
item.comment: Impression after one play: I liked this a lot, and it clearly has legs. Another classic goods-producing euro, nicely themed.

item.name: Gloom
item.comment: As a card game this is OK. For the components, see-through card mechanic and theme it is a very classy product. Mrs S does not like it, however.

item.name: Gloom of Kilforth: A Fantasy Quest Game
item.comment:
A really promising design. Synthesises a lot of elements from Runebound, Magic Realm and Arkham Horror into an involving, epic and (at lower player counts) fast-playing game. In its current incarnation, my preference is as a solo or 2p game, but could play well with larger groups, particularly who enjoy cooperation. Lots of scope for expansions. Publish this soon!
NB Rating is conservatively based on playing a late (but still not final) prototype.

item.name: Gloria Picktoria
item.comment: Quite playable two player, more interesting with three, and seems very clearly to be best with four and five. A very enjoyable game of scoring majorities with an element of pushing your luck. Total bargain for £2.99 at The Works.

item.name: Glory to Rome
item.comment:
Getting this knockd my interest in Wallace's London out - it is possible that there are only so many tableau-building card games one should own, and this is definitely one of them. It is the most interactive of any I've played so far (with the possible exception of 7 Wonders, although I think it may just about beat that on this score too). And it is simply fun to play.
Also, I like the cartoons, the plastic box (which is compact and durable), and the lurid game colours ASSIST PLAY. Layout is clever, and the 'broken' strategies also add to the enjoyment of this entertaining game.
I probably prefer Race for the Galaxy with 2, but this is the better for more players.

item.name: God's Playground
item.comment: I put a lot of work into learning the rules for this in the week before playing. I still don't quite know how the Hapsburg thing works, but on the whole it all makes sense once a game is under way. Came in a solid third, having failed to see which provinces were best to 'invest' in on the first turn, or at least that's my excuse. Even getting solidly beaten was not unenjoyable, and I would like a chance to have another shot at this. Very headachey, though, and seemed a bit more laboured than Byzantium.

item.name: Grass
item.comment:
Perfect for 4 to 6 players looking for some good-natured drug-dealing and ratting-out. Bought this and played the hell out of it after being "turned on" to it at a very crazy hippy party in a Moss Side tower block apartment in my misguided youth - about the only game I played in my 20s, apart from Risk ( until I got banned for boasting about cheating) and Shit Head.
My wife loves this game even though it should not really be considered playable with 2.

item.name: Guesstures
item.comment: Rating catagory: Party game This game has what it takes to make charades enjoyable for me. Speed charades, worth picking up from charity shop for those occasions when a group of reasonably outgoing people need a party game.

item.name: Gunslinger
item.comment: A splendid game. Fast, action-packed, deadly fun.

item.name: Haggis
item.comment: Currently the hot card game at home, taking the place of Cribbage and Mhing. It does make me feel a bit guilty about not spending more time and effort getting to learn traditional card games, rather than just trying what's 'hot' on the geek.

item.name: Hamburgum
item.comment: Played two player and for two games: excellent, if anything exceeded expectations. It takes a while to play, but thanks to the rondel, feels very pacey. I won by arund £50 in the first game, lost the second by a similar amoumt, which I think is an interesting situation for a zero-randomness game. I certainly prefer Imperial/2030, but this is really a very different game, particularly as it plays 2 player so well, closer to the niche of Brass, Puerto Rico and Powergrid. Mrs S loves it. Plus it cost £7.99 at the works - bargain. Nice bits!

item.name: Hansa
item.comment: Elegant strategic trading game. Fast playing (1/2 hr or less) with two, entertaining with four but more subject to AP

item.name: Hare and Tortoise
item.comment: Cartagena is much more likely to hit the table - this plays a bit too long. Like the new Gibson Games edition, though disappointed that the Liver Building is on the box but not the board!

item.name: Heroscape Master Set: Rise of the Valkyrie
item.comment: My wife picked this up in a charity shop, and although I was aware of the following for this game, I foolishly thought that was just owing to the prepainted minis. The game system is really good - simple, but dynamic and rewarding of thought and tactics. Plus very flexible - when I start playing this with my kids, I may bother to knock up cards for all the minis I have from various other games.

item.name: High Tail It!
item.comment: Takes a bit too long for my liking, and reminds me too much of draughts, which I am rubbish at and dislike. I could imagine getting into it though if someone was really keen to play, and if AP wasn't making the game torture.

item.name: Highland Clans
item.comment: Not a bad game at all - very nice components, a bunch of interesting mechanics, much more aggression than usually expected in euros. Swingy, subject to a bash-the-leader ethos, but so far quite fun.

item.name: Historia
item.comment: Much of the production is very nice, but overall I suspect that this game may actually be bad. It felt bland to play, it looked like certain strategies were inherently stronger than others, and the race to victory doesn't seem to hold surprises. Is it the mythical goal of a "1 to 2 hour civ game" that dominated design here? For a less-intense-civ-than-TTA I'd have to say Nations every time over this.

item.name: History of the World
item.comment: I liked this a lot but was happy to replace with Brief History. Advantages for Brief being a smaller box, slightly shorter play time and improved combat rules.

item.name: The Hobbit
item.comment: This is OK with kids. Nice production, somewhat bland play - a watered-down version of Knizia's Lord of the Rings.

item.name: Horus Heresy
item.comment: Fairly enjoyable, although the board design (such that the pieces can't actually stand up where they need to go) is annoying. From my limited experience, felt a little bit like Dune/Rex for 2.

item.name: Ice Flow
item.comment: Very enjoyable as a 2 player game. Nice bits.

item.name: Imperial
item.comment: If played a lot, I could get into this - have usually been voting for Powergrid for 6 players instead. Engineered myself out of controlling any countries for about an hour of the game, and still felt deeply involved, so there are certainly mechanics I like in this one. Edit Nov 09 - played a 6 player game of 2030 which was very painful, owing to having misremembered certain rules and having a poor start. Hopefully have now experienced the worst of this game. Hasn't put me off, but it reinforces the merits of eg Steel Driver, which is at least over in a reasonable length of time. Curious about trying the 2 player game

item.name: Imperial 2030
item.comment: Definitely more of a wargame than Imperial. Presence of many more neutral countries mean aggressive (imperialistic) expansion can pay off big. Any aggressive military strategy is still at risk of boardroom aggression, however - nothing worse than seeing the prize shares in a country you've built up going to a rival and profitting them. Intense.

item.name: Imperial 2030
item.comment: I may prefer this to Imperial, though it's a different game, and by no means necessarily better - much more of a wargame, which I think is owing to the greater abundance of neutral territories to invade into, making straightforward conquest startegies much more viable than in the original.

item.name: Imperial Settlers
item.comment: Enjoyable. Somewhat bland. The different decks for each player seems like a good feature, although in my limited play I didn't see much of the differentiation (if any).

item.name: Ingenious
item.comment: I like Ingenious, but I don't love it - it really does seem too tactical and the tactical choices never strike me as compelling - there's too much reacting to the last turn, scores have been close for me in almost every game - not always a bad sign, but in this case...
