Still, it isn't bad, and I really do like having games that take two minutes or less to explain to new players.

item.name: Ingenious: Travel Edition
item.comment: My wife loves Ingenious and usually wins. I find it a little bit lacking, and the production of the travel edition isn't great.

item.name: Innovation
item.comment:
Played at the end of a long day's gaming, with head a bit frazzled. Unsurprisingly given the circumstances, it didn't quite click. I can definitely see that improving with repeat plays. I completely misunderstood 'splaying' until long into the game, so need definitely need another shot at it. The play experience combines Glory to Rome with Wallace's London. Choices didn't feel at all intuitive, which isn't typical for 'civ' games, but again, this may well be owing to brain-fried-ness and unfamiliarity. Still, it seems you have to know the cards, and there a lot of cards to know. I don't think the same is entirely true with GTR, as that seems to me easier to see what is going on, and overall more funner. But first impressions can change, will see how I feel if I ever try it again.
Sept 2015 Edit: Well worth persevering with. Now I have picked up a copy, am getting a lot of play of this with the missus. At first she was outraged by the various 'wrecking' powers, but that only increased willingness to give it another try. Has taken over 2p slot for us - for how long?

item.name: Intrigue
item.comment: Backstabby fun. I can see that this one definitely depends on the group you play with (altho obviously that principal applies to everyt game - I suppose the point is that there are probably a lot of groups that Intrigue might at the very least fall flat with, if not provoke actual tears and fist fights)

item.name: Isolation
item.comment: Very cool original idea - draughts where you can move the pieces and move pieces of the board itself. Unfortunately the game itself doesn't really work, but as a genuinely original and intriguing idea it deserves kudos, and is well worth setting up and trying out. Just doesn't work as a game is all.

item.name: Judge Dredd
item.comment:
Damn fun game for Dredd fans. A few tweaks to get rid of the dice, and this would be released today as a best-selling euro (although I do tend to say that about quite a lot of games. Still, I think that the card-driven combat is none-too-shabby, and the "Take that! And that! And that!" element makes it very fun, as do the inevitable "Death selling Umpty Candy" "Angel Gang littering" mismatched crime situations.)
One of Games Workshop's best.

item.name: Kahuna
item.comment: This was quite fun, backwards-and-forwardsy two player. Liked it a lot, but not much need in my collection for more quick 2p type games so sold it. Recommended though.

item.name: Kargo
item.comment:
Great solitaire card game.
Edit : Or so I thought as a kid, for some reason. But it is a decent game for 3 or 4 players, and stands up very well against a lot of modern card games. Similar in play to Grass and (presumably) Milles Bournes, with a he'll of a lot of care put into implementing the theme.
A bargain for the prices one usually sees on eBay.

item.name: Ker Plunk
item.comment: As a party/dexterity game, Ker Plunk is not all bad. Kept us gripped as kids.

item.name: Key to the Kingdom
item.comment: Unless you have particularly resonant memories of this game from childhood, be warned that it is an utterly charmless piece of tat, without any interest or redeeming features.

item.name: King of Tokyo
item.comment: King of Tokyo seems to have the right elements for a light, fun dice game. I just don't get Zombie Dice, but this does have something like a game under the general excuse for silliness. Ridiculous RRP, though - no way I would pay over £15 - this is one that I am waiting to see turn up in the charity shops thanks to its relatively broad distribution.

item.name: Kingdom Builder
item.comment:
The overwhelming merit is replayability. Random r elements generally make the game lighter but do also provide for interesting choices. Nice bits!
For 2 players I strongly recommend mantuanwar's variant where one kingdom card is face up, and each player has one kingdom card that only they know - but which both players will score from. It adds exactly the right amount of uncertainty and potential for bluffing to spice the game up - possibly making KB a better game with 2 than more.

item.name: Kings & Things
item.comment: I bought this BITD when GW published it. Loved it for the art (which in common with a lot of people it seems I incorrectly attributed to the designer Tom Wham) and the humour (definitely Wham). I think I also however appreciated it for the game play. This might have been the nearest to a traditional war game that I played the most back then (probably a good dozen to twenty plays 2p and 3p). Recently picked up the Z-Man edition cheap (£10) and am reminded how much I like this game. Which is quite a lot. Necessary variant - take turns making one move at a time, then resolve fights (but allow blocking as per rules, unlike other foolish suggestions here on the geek)

item.name: Kings & Things*
item.comment: Kings & Things rocks.

item.name: Kingsburg
item.comment: (After 1 play, 4 player) Enjoyable, would certainly play again, but would generally prefer to play Caylus, which this feels similar too, wioth most choice and strategic potential of any decision removed. The dice-allocation mechanic is quite fun with 4, but it doesn't feel like the randomness adds an awful lot of value to the game, which is fine. A good 'gateway'? Maybe, but the apparently overwhelming choice of where to place dice, combined with the relatively low level of impact of good or bad decisions, might make this tedious if played between players of disparate skill levels. Nice bits, though.

item.name: Knightmare Chess
item.comment: Very fun idea for people who know the moves of the pieces but don't care much about the game itself. Extremely appropriate name

item.name: L-Game
item.comment: Interesting little 2 player abstarct. Suspect that that the pompoustext describing the invention of the game as the 'world's simplest boardgame' and how it is chock-full of strategy misses the fairly obvious point - it is impossible in the game to set up your opponent, and the best play can only ever consist of not playing the pieces so that your opponent can block you, and not failing to take advantage when they have left themselves open to such a play. I don't think that this really weighs in ,much as far as strategic depth goes, and would make the comparison with Rubik's Tic Tac Toe, which really does have the capability for strategic depth (again, I suspect). Quite an enjoyable short brain-stretcher, though.

item.name: Labyrinth
item.comment: Enjoyable game with the usual high quality Ravensberger components (rubbish art, though). Good game for kids, probably best with four for the chaos that would ensue ; playable with two, but not especially engaging.

item.name: Last Train to Wensleydale
item.comment: I like the Yorkshire Dales, Wallace games, wooden bits, so am happy with this, but could do with actually playing it some time. Next week, maybe. (Edit Feb 2011):Finally played, 4 player. Very enjoyable, interesting decisions, seems like the random set up should add enough variety to keep this replayable. Maybe the auctions aren't important enough, there often didn't seem to be any particularly bad or overwhelmingly great choices, so little bidding up in our game - can see this changing with experience. Love the implementation of theme in this, although I am particularly disappointede that Penrith is just labelled "The North", couldn't it at least be "Penrith & The North" - damn you, Mr Wallace.The gripes about the board? Pfft. The colour choices don't particularly disturb me, and while I can see how it all could have been made a bit better with firmer, slightly thicker lines between spaces, a little more space in a few spots in the Dales, there's a lot of information and (in the case of the locomotives) actual prettiness clearly and functionally presented. A turn summary on the board would have been very helpful, and the game has a degree of fiddliness that begins with set up and continues through applying the auction results (surprisingly difficult to manage this simple task whilst fielding rules questions or answering whether sugar is taken with your tea), to making the calculations about how much track to build/sell - but the game for me was definitely worth this. It isn't as intense as Brass, nor as breezy as London - close in other words to Tinners Trail, but somewhat inferior to that in terms of elegance. The counter-intuitive way that profit works is extremely entertaining, and surprisingly difficult to get a grasp of at first, resulting in a pleasingly bitter 'aha' moment when all your carefully orchestrated plans leave you with precious few VPs after the final round. 2014 Edit: My wife absolutely refuses to play this owing to the garishness of the board, which is very disappointing for me. At least the box is pretty, so it serves some purpose sitting on my shelf.Sigh.

item.name: Legendary Encounters: An Alien Deck Building Game
item.comment: Solid game. Seems to fix the only issue I had with Marvel Legendary - that the end game was too wonky. Maybe less inherent variability than Marvel, or leans more to a tendancy to play the classic movie scenarios? Shame that scalability is a bit of an issue - I'd mostly just want ot play this with 4 or 5.

item.name: Legendary: A Marvel Deck Building Game
item.comment: I have seen the light - this game really is a solid challenger to DOminin in my estimation. Incorporates elements of Nightfall and Ascension - both of which I personally pretty much loathe - into the deck management and point chasing of Dominion. Loads of interesting interactions in this game - like the way you can have a feel for the strategies available in a given set up by the types of cards expected in each heroes cards - but no guarantee that the killer combos will end up in your hand. Really, really good as a competitive game, plenty of opportunities in most set ups to spite your 'allies'. The master villain is such a great take on the Province Deck - victory points sitting outside your deck make decks generally more fun to play and less prone to choking, but there's still plenty of challenge in building a good deck. I think that people might have a bit less fun playing this purely cooperatively - would get too repetitive, be too long, and too easy - but maybe I am too competitive to appreciate that. Great design. The Punisher thinning out the Shield Agents in your deck being thematically explained as exterminating bent cops is one of the delightful little details.

item.name: Lewis & Clark
item.comment: This was fun, and I really like the art. It did feel a bit loose, but I haven't played it enough to know if it has legs.

item.name: Lexicon
item.comment: great card based word game. Each player has a hand of 10 letter card - first to play down all cards, either as complete words, or by inserting letters into previously played words to form a new word, wins the hand. Losing players total point value of the remaining cards in their hand. After eg 5 rounds, scores are totalled to determi e overall winner - lowest score wins. "The New Card Game of Skill, Laughter, and Interest."

item.name: London
item.comment:
Wallace does the card-laying-tableau-building thingy, and does it well. Surprisingly light, with a game length, load of vp calculating at game end, and dour art reminiscent of the old Ladybird books, that don't quite match with the lightness; so in all, a slightly odd beast. UI am guessing that at one stage before being simplified, the poverty cubes and other things actually went down on the map; the cubes and the board itself seem to be slightly out-of-place relicts of earlier incarnations.
I think it's likely that I prefer the game that exists in a parallel universe somewhere in which the board and actual location of developments (and poverty) have greater significance - but I do find I enjoy this version all the same.
As is typical with Mr Wallace, there are lots of very neat little ways that historical peculiarities and detail are worked into simple, abstracted mechanics.
Enjoyed 4 player the most so far (feels very urgent) - 2 player is excellent, but poverty doesn't quite seem to work (maybe we need to use strategies that take on loads of pov early on).

item.name: The Lonely Mountain
item.comment:
Used to play this solitaire a lot.
Quite a lot of similarities to Magic Realm, without the clever but brain-warping ruleset. I think if the board had been mounted, this might have been considered a classic today. Not a bad game at all, well worth considering if MR is your thing. On the whole though, this is the kind of game system people persevered with before computers could do it better.

item.name: Loopin' Louie
item.comment: Silly fun. I suck at it but think I should do better. Also, I prefer it when the batteries are worn down a little (newer version) - the slower Louie seems harder to hit, just leaving your paddle down won't automatically jump him, and the slow motion acrobatics are sublime.

item.name: Loot
item.comment: An enjoyable game. I like the way that cards are physically played, with the keel oriented to the player who played the card - both a useful way of indicating which card is which, but also a mechanic that leaves the table looking like there are little sea battles going on all over it. The colours can be hard to distinguish in poor light in the cartoony edition, I think I would prefer the older, drabber style, was that Korsar? I see that the mechanic is listed as "auction/bidding" rather than "trick taking", which makes sense now I think about it. This game is a classic Knizian combination of theme and mechanic, an aspect of his games that I suspect only elitist snobbery fails to recognise. Works with two, more fun with more, best with 3 or 4?

item.name: Lord of the Rings
item.comment:
I remember looking at this when it came out, being impressed by the weight of the box, then very disappointed on looking at the back to see that it was some kind of abstract game and nothing like Talisman. Picked it up for £1 in a charity shop - now I see what all the fuss is about. Great game.
Keep seeing this all the time in charity shops, but I have 3 copies and can't give any away - everyone either seems to have it, or hate it.

item.name: Lord of the Rings: Sauron
item.comment:
Makes winning for the Hobbits murderously difficult, bless 'em, in turn making keeping track of best score more meaningful. The Black Rider piece is great. Haven't dared to try the double-murderously difficult tile variant yet.
Rated as its own game

item.name: The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game
item.comment: Very enjoyable play, but I would really be most interested in this as a solo game and: 1) I generally prefer solo games where you only need to play one hand, and the scenarios just don't support that much - so much of good gameplay in LOTR is dependent on getting synergy with party-members. 2) Deck-building is shockingly poorly supported in the core set, and I cannot see myself investing the kind of money needed to properly get into this game. Still, if my wife liked it as much as I did then I would happily jump in. The art and production values are great, to my eye.

item.name: Lord of the Rings: The Confrontation (Deluxe Edition)
item.comment: I agree with the hate the insert crowd, very annoying, but irrelevant. Extremely satisfying game, great to play after an epic session of War of the Ring. Mrs schkff does not like, unfortunately.

item.name: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King Board Game
item.comment: Entertainingly lame rip off of the Knizia game - the Official Game of the Movie in the UK. May be fixable. Hard to imagine that anyone could even be bothered to play test this as it is practically unplayable. Roll dice, roll dice, roll dice, pick up cards, drop cards, roll dice... (1/2 hour later) play off a hand of cards, Sauron wins (or repeat earlier steps for another half hour, and another and another, and maybe the Fellowship will then win).
item.conditiontext: In good but used condition. Complete with the One Ring (not listed in contests, plastic - does not require disposal in Mount Doom)

item.name: Lords of Waterdeep
item.comment:
I like D&D, but the more 'Wonderful World of Dungeons and Dragons' the theming gets, the more my toes curl. Waterdeep really takes the biscuit in that regard. This game would be so much more tolerable with even just a generic fantasy theming, if a more interesting theme or background couldn't be found.
Anyhow, as a WP euro, its OK - it clearly rewards players who know the cards better (as do plenty of games, but there's something that feels very arbitrary about that here), but it's OK. I think in general, if I am going to play a Euro, I want it to be a really good euro, or else really quick.
Impressive but weird production values. The success does kind of surprise me, but it is well-earned for the effort that has gone into this.

item.name: Lost Cities
item.comment:
A neat enough game, but leaves me with the haunting feeling that there must be hundreds of better two player games with a standard deck of cards.
Also, rated a 6 to see if it provokes Mr Will Sargent to go all West Cumbrian on me.
So far, I live.

item.name: Lost Cities: The Board Game
item.comment: I have enjoyed the few plays I have had of this very much, and found it much more interesting than the card game. My wife loves it (and doesn't like the card game).

item.name: Lost Legends
item.comment:
Initial impression after a 2p play: Plusses - Game play: plenty of decisions to make, even if they aren't always deep ones; if someone gets far enough ahead and someone else is far enough behind, then there are no real catch-up mechanisms: boo-hoo. Personally, I found the game still to be fun in an agonising way when trailing in the dirt and tackling the L3 monsters with L1 weapons. Edit after 3 further 'proper' plays with 4 and 3 players: All this still holds. Have had one game with tense scoring and a close finish, and enjoyed another game where I played utterly hopelessly but still had a great time.
Production: the art is atmospheric, and there's a bit of consistency, eg in the way magic effects are portrayed (with glowing magical symbols, much as in numerous fantasy PC games but rarely seen in fantasy art - I kind of liked this). Card stock is great, and the cardboard used for the chips and player boards is solid German quality. The box is one of the sturdier ones I've come across too, and the insert's dividers are useful and look nice too. Plenty of room for expansion cards, neatly stored. Edit: All still good. Wish they'd gone for more differentiation on card backs for equipment and monsters, would make it easier to organise (not a huge problem though).
Doubts, minuses: Game play: Is it a bit long, for what it is? May become a slog, but I actually thought the game length was reasonable, just that there are some quicker filler games that might have more depth. It isn't long, though. Edit: I'm not finding it long, and am certain play would usually be comfortably under an hour with a little experience - for me that's filler territory. I think the pacing of the game is just right: doubt alleviated! Might it be dependent on expansions for variety? I will compare here to 7 Wonders, which I like, but has the similar issue that you draft through every card, every game. You don't necesssarily go through every monster, so you can't count on knowing exactly what you'll have to face, but because there are multiples of each monster type, you'll soon have seen them all. To go back to 7 Wonders, i've been happy to have some 21 plays without feeling the need to buy the expansions, even though the game lacks variety - if Lost Legions matches that I'd say it's a minor issue at worst. The strong get stronger and the weak get stomped: As remarked earlier, boo-hoo. Does every game have to have catch-up mechanisms that effectively penalise the leader to keep the game artificially close? The question is whether the game is still fun to play if losing. Personally, after getting stomped in one play I still enjoyed it - but will this continue to be the case? Will have to see. (Edit: still enjoying getting stomped after 4 plays...)
Component issues: As with 7 Wonders (or even more so in this case), quite a price tag for a fairly small pool of cards. I would say that as with 7 Wonders, if the game is good enough, this is a non-issue. The cover art is a bit disappointing compared to the quality of the art in the game. Better than many other games, and miniscule as an issue for me.
Verdict: Yet to see, but promising after some initial doubts. It is damn weird to see Queen take on the Fantasy card game genre, though. Damn weird!

item.name: Lost Valley of the Dinosaurs
item.comment: Not quite Atlantis, but the rubber dinosaurs and the pteradactyl make up for a lot.

item.name: Love Letter: Kanai Factory Limited Edition
item.comment: Enjoyable - these super-fast, moreish little games are a welcome trend. I have a bad taste Princess Di retheme in mind.

item.name: Machi Koro
item.comment: A decent enough game, with nice graphic design. The extremes of love and hate for it pass me by.

item.name: Mage Knight Board Game
item.comment: I enjoyed my one play of this, which was a 2player game, the other player helping me along with learning the rules as I went. The biggest turn off for me is that you only cycle through your deck a couple of times. It feels as though this would be a game that you'd get most out of solo, whilst yearning to have the multi-player experience with an equally matched opponent. Implements some ideas from Magic Realm well, and compared to that at least the rules are comprehendable, but I don't think this replaces its predecessor (nor indeed was it intended to, I'm sure). 2014 Edit: Now, I own the game, have got more plays in and am liking MK more and more. It is one of those games that really sticks in your mind after play (or during if you leave a solo game set up) - thinking about different ways it could play out. A surprisingly wide scope of ways to play, both from the subtle variation of scenarios and the very different approaches that can be taken during the game. The degree of determinism in the design fascinates me for some reason. I've particularly enjoyed multi-player, which can get long, although certainly afternoon-able when playing Blitz. I'm much less concerned about the limited cycling, which only becomes another strategic factor to consider when making card purchases - but essentially with MK, the 'deck-building' label doesn't really fit: for me, a deck-builder needs to have deck-thinning and cycling as more significant considerations in play.

item.name: Mage Wars Arena
item.comment: I am very impressed with Mage Wars. The two games I have played were very intense and thinky, but I can see how with familiarity it is likely to retain its richness whilst losing a little bit of the head-ache factor.

item.name: Magic Realm
item.comment: Difficult to rate... Has a lot going for it, scores highly as uniquely interesting, hell of an investment in time and effort to actually play it. Would probably take it to a desert island, can't see it getting much play otherwise. What's the rating for 'Outstanding game - too intimidating to even consider playing in most circumstances' . N/A will have to do for now. EDIT: April 2011 - Somehow, coming back to this after a hiatus helps, as does diving into RealmSpeak occassionally to see examples of the rules in play. Second time around is making much more sense, and I am enjoying this a lot more as a pastime and game, rather than as an acute mental workout. I am now considering trying to get this to the table with other humans - it can and must be done! EDIT: April 2013. Two years later, I have again traded away my own copy, but got to play with ANOTHER HUMAN on the p&p redesign. This is a great game. Set up and take down are frankly a chore, but it's worth the while, if only once every few years...
item.conditiontext:
Mostly in excellent condition - only played (carefully!) a few times. Most of the character pad unused. Box a bit battered but not excessively for age.
No original rule book present, and off hand I think there's one counter missing, a medium axe or something similar.
Limited trade interest - but would part ith this for maybe Space Empires 4X or possibly Mage Knight.

item.name: Magic: The Gathering
item.comment:
Yet to try this properly. I vaguely recall being aware of it but had pretty much finished gaming when it came out. Thanks to ebay and car boot sales I now have a stack of commons, and if I can ever persuade anyone to give it a try hope to build up a workable Cube.
Edit July 2011 - have started playing with the cube I put together a few months back. Not bad.

item.name: Manhattan
item.comment: More players the better. Very nice look at the end game. Feels like being in one of those pictures on the front of an 80s family game box - look of concentration whilst placing a last piece, the others looking on with merry smiles. Jerseys should be worn to play this game, and with a son and daughter of similar age, and freckled faces.

item.name: Marvel Dice Masters: Uncanny X-Men
item.comment: I've played a little with my son, with a largish but by no means complete collection. I like it a heck of a lot more than I did Quarriors.

item.name: Mastermind
item.comment: Yeah, it's a solitaire puzzle requiring an enabler, but nostalgia at least makes this a fun filler now and then.

item.name: Mecanisburgo
item.comment: This is a good game. My only play was in less than ideal circumstances, standing in for a player who dropped out just after the rules explanation, in a game of six players I think, where no one had played before. But the game shone through. Everything and the kitchen sink thrown into this one, but it is well worth persevering with.

item.name: MegaCorps
item.comment:
Impression after first play: Interesting. Mrs S drew blood scratching my arm after I persuaded everybody else to donate mercenaries to block her attempted takeover of Russia on turn 1. This certainly seems to be a game with the potential to provoke hurt feelings... Negotiation is an essential element, of the type euro players usually rule illegal in superficially similar games. Similar in this sense to Intrige.
I ended up winning with around 200 points, my nearest competitor had about 100. I didn't control any countries for the last couple turns - early on, while other players went for more obvious targets, I surreptitiously cornered the market in metal, took a no-contest, 4 share payout, then continued to capitalise on this from a happy coincidence in the event cards I drew (including the 'immediate payout for metal' card that I didn't know about before drawing it). After my second payout I became a target, following the third players went all out and worked together against me, but by then it was already far too late. Am interested to see how it plays with players who have an idea what to look out for, eg: in this game, if players had acted earlier, they could have taken metal shares themselves, kicked me out, or either left me holding the paid card, or otherwise made sure that somebody took a payout before the choice came back to me.

item.name: Memoir '44
item.comment:
Secret Thrifty Santa gift 2010 - thank you thrifty santa! Very much!
So far Mrs Schkff has actually even suggested the plays of this - quick playing time is a definite plus.
I am very much enjoying 'wargames' with card/dice driven command choices (Memoir, Yankees & Rebels, War of the Ring). The division of the left, center and tright flanks feels a bit more limiting and artificial than command dice, but plays well as a game mechanic, and is thematic enough.
Intend to pimp my copy out with some Airfix 1:72 troops before too long. I can only imagine how I would have loved to own this game 30 years ago, and hope to vicariously enjoy that experience with my son in a couple years time.

item.name: Merchant of Venus (second edition)
item.comment:
Although I wanted to like this anyway, it is continuing to grow on me, and I think I'm seeing increasing depth, as a result of which I am enjoying the game more and more. Movement is a particular delight.
Haven't played the 'Standard Game' - will probably try it eventually solo. I'd like to figure out a way to use some of the nice bits for Standard in the Classic Game.
I never played the original, but have done my best to study up the differences. I am inclining to 'house rule' that factory goods can't earn demand bonuses, as factories played very strong in our first few games and they seem to need to be trimmed back to the original edition's strength. Not sure about the missing orbit point - if it was left out for balance then the new edition's map might be worth sticking with.
FFG seem to have taken a bit of a kicking over this one. The differences between this edition's Classic game and AH PnP are minor and easily changed; the design is perfectly functional and it is nice-looking. I like the corny 50s/60s SF art of the original edition, but the cover is great on this new game, really in the spirit of the game, but different, and new. The board is entirely functional (although you do have to unfold it carefully). And maybe the Standard game is a mess (don't know, haven't tried it), but I am sure that eventually someone could come up with some neat variants by cannibalizing the pieces/rules.
The money is pretty crap, but entirely a non-issue for me - I have plenty alternative chips and money sets, so very rarely use the money in a given game anyway. Game designers - please do keep your printing costs down by including crappy money in your games, I implore you!
I would run out and buy an Ace Trucking retheme in a heart beat, though. 10-10, good buddies!

item.name: Merchants & Marauders
item.comment: I really liked this. I don't know if the game length is justified though unless playing with people who like it at least as much as I do, otherwise it may begin to drag. For me, the combination of trading, adventuring, conflict, and the hazards of chance are all at about the right dosage. 9 times out of 10 I'd recommend playing Merchant of Venus over it, though.

item.name: Merkator
item.comment: I felt very well inclined towards this game owing to the large number of coloured cubes; after playing I have discovered that I am absolutely delighted by Merkator, which is filled from the beginning with interesting decisions. In spite of the obvious cube-shuffling agenda, I was surprised to read the many negative comments here, deriding the dryness and lack of theme. I find that the time element and the yeah generally the whole way that cubes sorry goods and contracts are handling is nicely thematic, but horses for courses I suppose. Here's hoping that the disdain means that I will be able to pick up a copy on the cheap before too long. Trade for London, anyone?

item.name: Mhing
item.comment: Wonderfully produced. 'Games played' is for actually whole plays to a score of 500, which has been taking the missus and I at least three hours spread over 2-3 days per game. Now the missus is starting to beat me hand after hand, its appeal is starting to wear off for me. The solid plastic card well is a great prop for any card game with a draw and discard pile.

item.name: Middle-Earth Quest
item.comment:
I really like the card system for movement/combat/injury and exhaustion - very reminiscent of the chit system from Magic Realm, maybe even an improvement on it.
Overall, the design on this feels tighter to me than other FFG adventure games such as Android and Arkham. I was a bit disappointed that it wasn't set in a completely different time from the War of the Ring, but this is a decent game. Plenty of interesting choices for Sauron and fun for the heroes.

item.name: Mille Bornes
item.comment: French "Deluxe" edition. Nice artwork etc. Better suited to two than Grass.

item.name: Ming Dynasty
item.comment: Notorious 'Works Bargain'. Not really a bad area-majority game, with very nicely-produced pieces.

item.name: Mistfall
item.comment: From one 3 player game: a robust concoction of elements from Pathfinder and Mage Knight. Problems include down-time, numerous vaguely-worded effects and for me some of the bite of MK and the light fun of PF. Pluses include the sense of adventure, the variety of setup, the effort to create an integrated, atmospheric theme (charmingly reminiscent of Runequest). It's a decent effort, but falls short of both its progenitors for me.

item.name: Mona Lisa Mysteries
item.comment: Very random play, but good quick fun. Nice components, enjoyable Gateway-Gateway game. £1.99 at Home Bargains!

item.name: Monopoly
item.comment: Put me firmly in the "Monopoly really has a lot more going for it than this site usually credits, yes I have plenty other games I'd play first, but if some non-gamery person wants to play, Free Parking cash and all, I'll happily join them, and mock dogopoly if you must, should they print Mongolopoly or some other theme perfectly suited to my tastes then hell, I'd probably buy the thing, that said, you've got to make the occasional crack about the game, it's Monopoly for chrissakes, and I hope you'll never find me posting one of those "Actually, if you play without Free Parking cash and with the auction rules printed" comments, although that said...(etc.)" camp.

item.name: Monopoly Deal Card Game
item.comment: Well, it's ok. Way too random for two player longevity, may be fun with more, esp. as a family game. A lot of grey areas thrown up by the rules.

item.name: Monopoly Express
item.comment: Fun push-your luck dice game, nice bits. The dice trays in the Express games are excellent, we always use them whenever playing games with dice.

item.name: Monsters Menace America
item.comment:
2 player game was disappointingly flat, pretty pointless. I can see 4 player being more fun with people in the right mood for it. Maybe three player controlling two monsters each?
Will try to hang onto this until my son (currently 3) is old enough to play. At the moment he LOVES playing with the monsters and tanks - who can blame him? so do I - but there really isn't enough game there for full adult attention.

item.name: Montego Bay
item.comment:
Played two player so far. This is an excellent game, very entertaining, the right level of screwage to make a fast euro interesting.
The overproduction is quite amusing: enormous board, superfluous tallymeeple

item.name: Mr. Jack Pocket
item.comment: I've never played the original, but I do like this, and am generally a fan of quick 2 player abstracts. To be honest, the biggest attraction for me was the compact box and the nicely produced bits.

item.name: Munchkin Deluxe
item.comment: Is there anybody looking? Ok, I'll be quick: I quite like Munchkin. :runs away:

item.name: Municipium
item.comment:
A very enjoyable game. Shocking to think what people who paid the full price might feel about it, but well worth the £10 that a number of online stores are flogging it for now.
Edit: Now that, thanks to the Works £7.99 sale I have a number of games with similar mechanics but nicer bits (particularly Royal Palace), this has dropped in my estimation.

item.name: Mythotopia
item.comment:
After only one play - so take this with a pinch of salt - but I am suspicious of the way the end game plays out. It doesn't feel right - and in my one play was down right horrible and disappointing. Discworld and A Study in Scarlet both seem to handle end game better in the faced of similar potential issues - and it may well come down to the lack of hidden goals of some sort - with the deterministic end conditions, players are either going to be stupid, fatalistic, or else drawn into tedious bash-the-leader jockeying.
The rest of the game was great, though, and I loved the art and the place names.

item.name: Nations
item.comment: Extremely enjoyable, TTA-lite. I would go for the real thing for 2p, but this is fun, and very accessible.

item.name: Nations: The Dice Game
item.comment: Pretty decent game. I'd certainly just as soon play Nations, but this was all right.

item.name: Navia Dratp
item.comment:
Beautiful pieces, enjoyable meeting of anime and chess. Advantage over chess is that it has to play quicker, as players win goolyhoo stones for every capture. I think it's a mistake to view this as making a better game, but can certainly be more fun for lighter play.
Great value for the current prices available (thrifted my set for 99p!)
Love the silly names- all part of the appeal. Real men pronounce the silent t in Dratp!

item.name: Nightfall
item.comment: No doubt I haven't played this enough, but I really didn't like it. The early Dominion-inspired designs all seem to be fundamentally flawed as games (this, Ascension and presumably Thunderstone) - seeing the lack of theme in Dominion and not even bothering to emulate the richness of gameplay.

item.name: No Thanks!
item.comment: Compelling, fast, bidding game.

item.name: Notre Dame
item.comment: Very nice. Played 2 player, plays very well, races along very happily.

item.name: Oasis
item.comment: Very enjoyable area control game with a novel gift-giving 'auction' mechanic. The Mongolian theme is very nicely applied (except, frustratingly enough, in the title). High production values, particularly with the inclusion of cameeples! Seems to be widely available at a discount - strongly recommended.

item.name: Once Upon a Time: The Storytelling Card Game
item.comment: For the right circumstances. A very enjoyable and nicely produced thing, somewhat more 'creativity tool' than game.

item.name: One Night Ultimate Werewolf
item.comment: Yar, never actually played Werewolf, but I liked this.

item.name: Onward to Venus
item.comment: Really like the production values, and found it fun, but nothing really stood out. The missus hated it!

item.name: Opera
item.comment: Beautiful components, and an excellent choice of theme for this Wallacesque take on Puerto Rico. Other games tend to get chosen first, but hopefully one to play occassionally for the change of atmosphere. Plays pretty well 2 player, well with 4, possibly best with 3?

item.name: Ora et Labora
item.comment:
Enjoyed my play of this. Probably wouldn't suggets it, but would be happy to play if it was brought to the table. Does possibly seem (as with Mr Feld's games) that there might be so many different ways to score points that everything will work out nearly equally well - until players get experience with the system. A little less fiddly than Agricola, and with the swinginess of the cards removed, is how I feel about it. If we didn't already own Agricola and instead wound up with this, I think we'd be quite happy with it. So for me solid, worthwhile, but ultimately doesn't quite set me on fire.
Thinking about this reminds me that the not-so-much-loved Mercator has the enormous benefit of simplicity/quick game time.
I am a fan of Uwe, but not really a follower (and STILL not played Le Havre...)

item.name: Oregon
item.comment: Fun enough worker placement with pretty pieces and some neat mechanics. Shame there's no way to gun down your rivals though.

item.name: Othello
item.comment: Is this one of those games that people complain about being 'solved'? It certainly has puzzle qualities, it may be solvable, but I certainly enjoy playing it casually from time to time. A good one to play with kids to teach the important concept that what looks like avery good move in the short time can actually be a very bad move indeed.

item.name: Outpost
item.comment: I suppose it is worth considering owing to the range of player numbers it supports, but I didn't enjoy this at all. Phoenicia is better balanced, if ultimately no less forgiving. Luck of the draw in the first half dozen rounds is crucial, and the range of values on resource cars can lead to brutal differences in players' buying power. Waiting for people to count their card values or decide if they even want to bid in the auctions is tedious. Probably tolerable if players are all concentrating on what they are doing and have played it before. And does it always take forever? I thought I liked auction/economic games before playing this museum piece.

item.name: Palace
item.comment: i.e. Shit-head

item.name: Pandemic
item.comment: Great fun with 2 players, may be more difficult to get the right balance of personalities with more, as the 'co-operation' usually boils down to agreeing with the person who's right - it seems extremely difficult to win unless almost every aspect of the player's actions are coordinated.

item.name: Pass the Bomb
item.comment: Don't seem to have bothered logging my plays of this, but it certainly works well with "non-gamers" + alcohol.

item.name: Pass the Bomb: Party Edition
item.comment: A whole boxful of varients, some of which require more alcohol to be consumed before attempting to enjoy.

item.name: Pass the Pigs
item.comment: "Makin' bacon." Hurr-hurr.

item.name: Pathfinder Adventure Card Game: Rise of the Runelords – Base Set
item.comment:
After playing two sessions (at the end of the second Lem slung a final, desperate spell and slew the dragon! Epic stuff!) I am very impressed with this game.
The system of slowly evolving your character's stats and deck is simple but extremely effective and addictive. The designer of this game deserves all the accolades and glory for coming up with a way to have persistent characters and progression in a board game (ok, card game, but same thing). This is quite possibly the Holy Grail of adventure game design, and what springs from it We Shall See. Bravissimo!
I really am not keen on the LCG/expansion model for games, but I do think that anyone who buys into this will get themselves a great package and find good value for money. It seems to me that there is a hell of a lot of replayability in the base game - quite possibly in boardgaming terms infinite replayability - it's just that you are going to really want to take the adventure further and keep buying the adventure packs. If I was allowed to spend my money as I pleased (ie not married) then this wouldn't give me even a moments' pause (but then again if that was so I'd already have long since blown any cash on whatever was the hottest game/expansion series five years ago, and be up to my ears in debt, so I am not complaining, honest).
The game play itself may not be everybody's cup of tea, and that's understandable. Maybe the next game to come along which learns from this design will be able to come up with something more impressive in that area. But personally I have enjoyed the game play, and the simple but satisfying decisions and agonies over whether to play this or that card, and the little calculations about which combination of polyhedral dice gives the best chance at a positive result.
Please can somebody get the license to produce an Adventure Time version of this game, preferably standalone. I will buy that.

item.name: Pax Porfiriana
item.comment: One play was not enough to appreciate the richness of this, but I liked it and would definitely play again. Intense! Really enjoy the graphic design, too.

item.name: Peloponnes
item.comment: Very enjoyable blend of auction and civ mechanics. Curiously, best with 1 or 4 players. Questionable how much strategy can beat luck, but the game is quick and involving, and there's a nice meanness to the auctions.

item.name: Pentago
item.comment: Very entertaining little two playere abstract. As a tic tac toe variant, it loses out to Rubik's Tic Tac Toe in terms of elegance and (for me) compulsion, but wins for Nice Bits. Have both the plastic swivel section and solid birch editions, thanks to charity shops. Trade, anyone?

item.name: Perudo
item.comment: Dice, bluffing, odds guessing, quick : fun game. Prefer to play where an incorrect guess etc loses just 1 die. Keep picking these up in charity shops, so hope to have a monster 20 player game sometime, however stupid that may be.
item.wantpartslist: Want 1 black cup from the FX Bluff edition.
item.haspartslist: some spare cups from the later less fancy edition of Perudo

item.name: The Phantom League
item.comment:
(I only ever played this with the Mostly Harmless expansion included.)
There's a lot to like about this if you are looking for a space adventure game. Most of the production values are extremely good - I like the art, the graphic design, the thickness of tiles and the discs used for player pieces.
The game's biggets flaws are a result of loosness of design: so if you are only interested in complete, rigorously-playtested, fat-trimmed games you should avoid this like the plague.
To me, it feels more like a GM-less space RPG, including the need to fudge rules, make up interpretations on the spot, and to be more interested in the experience than winning. Drawing tons of cards every turn grew tiresome, altho I did like the general balance of what was on the cards, and think it reflected the source material (ie Elite computer game) well.
The combat system is at first a little bizarre, but I am a fan of card-based systems eg the various ones in FFG games (Rune Wars, Star Craft). This is a worthy and novel addition to those, but not quite as tight, far less of a draw (more something that just works out as OK).
A revised 2nd edition in about 5 years time could be really interesting. If you are looking for a game that is somewhere between Merchants of Venus, Eclipse, and Arkham Horror, this might be the game for you, especially if you are not afraid of making your own adjustments to get the game working better.

item.name: Phoenicia
item.comment: It isn't my only criteria by many means - indeed I live lots of games that I suck at (eg Powergrid and Steel Driver) - but I find it hard to resist the charm of a game that I won first time. Go me. Auction / Civ building / Worker-placement - a nice balance of all three for a quick game, which has the merit of giving room for a runaway leader - god knows, if every frikkin game you play has 5 points between first and last place, it gets a bit tiresome after a while. Wooden pieces would be preferred, but the White plastic almost seems a bold and outrageous attack on convention.

item.name: Pickomino
item.comment: Good family game. Lovely bits!

item.name: Piece o' Cake
item.comment: A very enjoyable game of cake-slicing. One to look out for as a fun, family-friendly filler, folks.

item.name: Pirates of the Caribbean: Trading Card Game
item.comment: Meh. Very cheap though, and the boxes are useful for better card games.

item.name: Pit
item.comment: Very enjoyable game. One of the classics it's nice to introduce new players to. Have a traditional set, and a 'Billionaire' set which has ugly cards, but excellent paper money to keep score. Need to get a bell.

item.name: PitchCar
item.comment:
Superb game. If I had the space I would love to own, but the mini version is fine for a normal-sized house.
Edit : Bought it as a Xmas present for my foster -siblings - now I can play it whenever I'm visiting the Old Home Place.

item.name: PitchCar Mini
item.comment: This game makes me very keen to upgrade to a larger house, kitchen and therefore bigger table, so I can try out the full size version. Until then mini will more than do. Will start buying the expansions once the novelty of the base game starts to wear thin. Edit : bought expansion 2, well worth getting. Hugely popular game to spring on non-gamers. My love for this game has only increased over time, which is rare enough. Also acted as a spur for me to try Carrom, which is superb.

item.name: Poker
item.comment: We play low-stakes all-night Texas Hold'em with Mongolian friends who have the bug. I would rather get them into Bucket King or Bohnanza, but for some folks there has to be real money on the table for a game to be worth playing - and Hold 'em certainly is good for that.

item.name: Port Royal
item.comment: Theme is pasted-on like a costume store pirate beard and eye-patch, but if I can ever persuade 3 people to join me for an hour long trick-taking game with all the excitement in the last round, I'm looking forward to playing this one. [Edit after one play] Really enjoyed this, hope to get to play again soon. Difficult to persuade people when they have other options!

item.name: Portobello Market
item.comment:
Bought on the strength of all the comments here which highlighted the speed of play, accessibility to new gamers, depth and variety of playing strategies.
What a great find.
Cracked it open when my brother and his other half were visiting (not exactly boardgamers, although I have previously subjected them to Talisman and Settlers at successive xmases). Game went phenomenally well, they loved it, my brother occassionally murmuring in stunned surprise "This really is a good game."
Serious contender for my first '10' rating, although with my butterfly taste in gaming experiences, I am not sure that that is ever achievable by BGG criteria.
Edit : the novelty has worn off a bit as a 2 player, for which I would usually prefer to go for Hansa or Cartagena. Still think it's a first rate game for it's niche, which would be 3-4 players, fast play, accesible depth.

item.name: Poseidon
item.comment: I don't know enough about 18xx games to be a judge, but it feels to me that this may be lacking in oomph to be much of an introduction to the genre - that you may as well play an 18xx inspired but not derived game (eg Steam, Chicago Express) or the real thing... but maybe this is the real thing, I don't know. Very nice components though.

item.name: Power Grid
item.comment: After one play : stands up to the hype. Preferable to the Ticket to Ride Games, which I am happy to play but find largely frustrating. I am rubbish at this game, but always enjoy it. Love the theme, components, and delightfully drab art. The euro that deserves to be heir to Monopoly's throne.

item.name: Powerboats
item.comment: Very nice components, simpler play than Formula D, faster and possibly funner too. Marred if played conservatively.

item.name: Puerto Rico
item.comment: After one play : would definitely play again, but I wasn't all that thrilled. After many more plays, mostly 2 player : I like PR. Great fun as long as all parties know or are quick to pick on how the game is played.

item.name: Quads
item.comment: Interesting blocking game for 2, with very nice production values (gigamic). A good 15 minute abstract, of about light to medium depth.

item.name: Quarriors!
item.comment: Rolling dice is fun. 'deck' builders where the choice is to buy the best card (or dice) available and hope for a lucky draw (roll) do a lot to show just how awesome a job Vaccarino managed with Dominion.

item.name: Quick Chess
item.comment: Very good for introducing the game to new players, and the retheming is awesome!

item.name: Quoridor
item.comment: One of the very best 10 minute games. Silly fun with 4, tense and tactical for 2.

item.name: Quoridor Mini
item.comment: A good little game for two, silly but fun for four.

item.name: Qwirkle
item.comment: I like Qwirkle. The colour scheme bugs me, although the game does at least play a good function in the colour-blindness department by helping raise awareness of how colour-blindness can affect a game - because when my tiles are standing up I am damned if I can tell the difference between blue & green and orange & red.

item.name: Ra
item.comment: Both 5 player games were frustrating owing to feeling of inability to affect flow of game much, and also owing to lack of enthusiasm from some players. Seems to play wonderfully well two player, which I have really enjoyed, I would guess three maybe four is best. Beautiful components.

item.name: Race for the Galaxy
item.comment: No other game in my collection has come close to Race for replayability. This year we finally mixed in Brink of War. It's seen steadily increasing plays between my wife and me year on year for 5 years now, which has got to mean something. If we're in a hurry, we can get a game set up and played in about 12 minutes, though usually we take our time and make it a luxurious 25 minute experience. And we're STILL noticing little details on the card art. Best game of 21st Century. If learning the icons is a struggle for you, it may be worth weighing that against the likelihood of getting hundreds of plays out of the game.

item.name: Race for the Galaxy: The Gathering Storm
item.comment: Rated and plays logged for the solo game. I love the iconography in Race anyway, the Robot takes that to a whole other level.

item.name: Rack-O
item.comment: Quite enjoyable game for two - with more players, use the cards to play No Thanks

item.name: Railway Rivals
item.comment: Played this a fair bit when GW first published it. The race part of the game would really need some working on to bring the game up to 21st century standards, but it is still worth playing.

item.name: Raj
item.comment: I don't log all my plays, but my kids (since ages 3-5-7) absolutely love playing this. Biding my time to move them on to For Sale.

item.name: Recon Strategy
item.comment: I am entirely convinced of the awesome merits of this game!

item.name: The Resistance
item.comment: I enjoyed this but haven't played enough to appreciate whether I really like it.

item.name: Rex: Final Days of an Empire
item.comment: Only one play - liked it, but found the card-knowledge issues a bit of a frustration - getting hosed by cards that you didn't even have an inkling of is a bit annoying, and suggests that you need a group to play this exclusively for a while to really appreciate it. Obviously, TI theme is pants compared to Dune, but otherwise I think FFG did a good job.

item.name: Risk
item.comment:
An enjoyable, simple family game of global carnage. Somewhat tending to the overlong in the standard world domination variant - mission Risk usually brings the game down to within 2 hours.
Played a lot with school mates in my late teens, I had the usual contempt for this game of people who have played better. Later boasted of cheating (which I very much assumed everyone was doing). As a result I have been officially labelled The Risk Cheater and banned from playing for life. Ironically, this has increased the pleasure I get from playing the game on odd occasions now (please be assured, there is no cheating ).

item.name: Risk Express
item.comment: The Risk game it's geeksocially acceptable to own!

item.name: Risk: Balance of Power
item.comment:
This has all the faults of standard risk - except for play time. There are hints of potential strategy, but its a tough game to win if you get just a few unlucky rolls at the wrong time.
But it also has all the attractions of Risk, and more (the shared bonus objectives are a touch of genius) - plus, the likelihood is that you're only ever going to find at most one other person up for a game of Risk in this day and age, so Balance of Power should be the automatic choice.
Added bonus: compactness, always a merit (and rare enough these days).

item.name: Risk: The Lord of the Rings
item.comment: Need to try again - think that 2 player may work better with 2 armies each. Board is indeed very hard to read in lots of places, which is silly. Nice pieces. Great value as a thrift game. Ring movement mechanism is frankly wierd, particularly as delaying the Fellowship is just as likely to benefit the Good as the Evil side - but a turn limit is useful in Risk.

item.name: Risk: Transformers
item.comment: A fun, thoroughly playable Risk variant. The 6 turn limit should maybe be adopted in the standard game. And the little robots are cool, as are the various zone names : "Optimus Prime and his robots are attacking Praetorius Wharf from their foothold in Nova Cronum!" "Just make sure he keeps the hell out of the Rad Zone!" Wow!
item.conditiontext: Still as new, all pieces present. Would preferably trade for some other Risk variant, as I would happily own the lot, but I suppose that one at a time should do.

item.name: Robinson Crusoe: Adventures on the Cursed Island
item.comment: I did enjoy this, and love the graphic design, but it is altogether too much effort of learning and interpreting the rules to be something I would bother with. The world of co-ops needs more designs like this, though.

item.name: Roll for the Galaxy
item.comment:
Nice production, fun game. I wouldn't really choose to play it over Race myself, but would be happy to play it if somebody else preferred it. I don't think it's as deep, but it certainly isn't a throwaway game. My honest advice would be to buy Race plus one of the base+1 expansions (Gathering storm, Alien Artifacts) for the money, but I think the dice have a lot of plastic appeal for people at the moment.
Was nice to see more of the original art, owing to the different shape of the tiles to the cards.

item.name: Roll Through the Ages: The Bronze Age
item.comment:
Have to agree that there's some shoddy production on this one. Don't really have a problem with the Yahtzee Through The Ages concept though, but maybe it should be licensed to Parker?
Edit: Better value on the iPhone.

item.name: Roma
item.comment: Roma is an absolute gem of a game. Plays can take 5 minutes, or can swing one way then the other for almost an hour (so don't play it if you need to fit in a quick filler before work). Damn fun, though. The Mercator is so not broken.

item.name: Rosenkönig
item.comment: Superb two-player. As familiarity increases, it really comes down to the luck of the draw, but the game remains enjoyable, perhaps more so. Good for practising yer sums!

item.name: Royal Palace
item.comment: (Bought as part of the great £7.99 Works sale of 2011): I am not a fan of Michael Menzel per se, although I respect his work and find the world of euro games to be richer for it, but this one is an absolute gem, and clearly a labour of love. The gameplay? I like it, and my wife loves it.

item.name: Rubik's Tac Toe
item.comment:
Strangely compelling. Can be played in the rain or in raucous pubs without worries of spillage. Is it really that much deeper than regular tic tac toe? I don't know - which is one reason I find it compelling.
Always room in my collection for games that take 2 - 10 minutes to play.
item.wantpartslist: Missing 1 circle plastic tile (Rubik's Magic edition)

item.name: Rummikub
item.comment: I guess the point of having tiles rather than 2 decks of cards is that it makes hands more manageable. I have a travel edition with tiny wee chips, but enjoy the tactile pleasure of the full size bakelite set.
item.wantpartslist: Missing 2 tiles from travel edition (blue 9 and a joker)

item.name: Runebound (First Edition)
item.comment: Enjoyable, nice effort on components, mechanics and theme. 'Multi-player solo' criticisms largely valid. Not sure I'd pay price for 2nd ed when 1st now so cheap, however great the improvements. Really enjoyed my first play, but the 'flavour text' loses its appeal after that.

item.name: Runewars
item.comment: I found one 4 player, 5 hour play of this (epic rules, expansion included) extremely enjoyable, although I have a few reservations about replayability. Only fully realized the importance of questing towards the end of the game (a common mistake I understand); the randomness here, that one player could feasibly get 3 runes through the course of the game (or more?) whilst the others keep drawing nothing but duds has the potential of making a sideshow of everything else. If a player doesn't need to attack to get Runes then they could probably turtle with great effect. Nonetheless, it was great fun, I pretty much liked how all the various mechanisms played - simultaneous action selection, the dilemma of choosing action order, card combat, and so on. As is often the case with FFG, the mechanisms were all half familiar from other games - elements here of Game of Thrones, the first Warcraft boardgame, Runebound-in-miniature, Starcraft TBG simplified: For me, this is a great mix. I am very likely to swallow my reservations and spring for the reprint when it comes out, even if it only ends up seeing play once every year or so.

item.name: Samurai & Katana
item.comment: From the few plays (which included house rules such as taking actions in turn rather than whole turns), this seems to be a really solid multi-player conflict game. The way you can inflict damage even if you lose a fight is nasty (a good thing of course),and the hand management aspect is very strong (again, possibly played with some house rules).

item.name: San Juan
item.comment: Mostly played 2 player with the missus. An enjoyable way to fill 30-40 minutes. A substitute for RFTG for me, which Mrs dislikes owing to theme and iconography. Edit (Oct 2010): Now Mrs schkff has converted to RFTG, so maybe I can trade this?

item.name: Scoop
item.comment: Very decent game for its age, although the 'lines down' rule tends to wreck play. The fake '50s news stories are entertaining, sense of satisfaction from completing a front page is rewarding. And that phone gizmo, how the hell does it work (and how the hell does it STILL work 50 years later?)
item.conditiontext: Worn, but complete 1950 edition (only 4 newspapers, 2-4 players only).

item.name: Scopa
item.comment: We learned this visiting friends in Italy, and got quite hooked. The social aspect is definitely one of the things that makes it great - this does arise, however, as a result of the lightness which nonetheless includes gameplay elements that aren't entirely devoid of thought or skill. It feels quite like a modern light euro card game in that regard. Scopa!

item.name: Scotland Yard
item.comment: Great, simple game, with very nice production values from Ravensburger. Fury of Dracula without the fiddly bits.

item.name: Scrabble
item.comment: Love Scrabble, hate the official dictionary. The printed rules require a 'standard' dictionary, which is an entirely different thing : you won't find qi or za in one. I like the way that players with a better vocabularly are handicapped by the compulsion to show off, even where a shorter word would score more. Must be played with a dictionary that includes a good range of swears.

item.name: Scrabble: Simpsons Edition
item.comment: The production is nice, and as a variant there is some silly Scrabble/Simpsons-themed fun (KYJIBO!) The board is double-sided, so you can play regular scrabble with it, which is what we usually do.

item.name: Seasons
item.comment: Nothing particularly grabbed me with this one, it felt too faffy. May well reward a deeper investment of time and interest. Not for me.

item.name: Sekigahara: The Unification of Japan
item.comment: The big problem for me with this game was thinking about other two player conflicts I'd rather play in its place. It feels like the kind of game you shoulod really commit to, play almost exclusively. Tense play.

item.name: Senet
item.comment: Not bad at all, and pretty. Fun throwing the sticks. Something awesome about playing a 5000 year old game.

item.name: Sentinels of the Multiverse
item.comment: Impressive variety in set up, nice to play with a choice of premade decks. Really like the art style, 80s indy superhero ethic FTW!

item.name: SET
item.comment: This has gone down very well with groups of teenagers - good for camping trips and as a filler with a group that don't want a ton of rules.

item.name: The Settlers of Canaan
item.comment:
What I like about this edition: Not having to set up the board, the board not being at risk of disintegration during play; the gloomy public domain Victorian bible art, and the "Made in North Carolina" banner; the 'building Jerusalem' mechanic is a good addition to the game, allowing another way to score and ease trading, and acting as a game clock; the fact that the rules and components are pretty much otherwise vanilla Settlers; that you can use Cities and Knights and play "Crusaders of the Holy Land".
What isn't so great: the black and the blue Jerusalem bricks are the most indistinguishable game components I have yet seen - in one sense this does provide for a deeply challenging bonus game, in most other senses, this is a bit of a silly oversight, to say nothing of the note offering $5 off other games in the stable as compensation for the tiles being too big (can I sue if I follow their Exacto-knife easy-alteration directions and slice off a thumb?); although the Jerusalem mechanic does something for it, this is hardly any more of a 2 player game than vanilla Settlers, especially as the map is non-customizable, and thus too big.
Would I buy this in place of vanilla Settlers? Being someone who only plays occassionally, yes, providing this were cheaper, which I believe it usually is.
Overall verdict: this retheming fits really well, especially being built on a solid pun; I would be curious to see biblical reinterpretations of other popular board games...

item.name: The Settlers of Catan
item.comment: Like a gazillion other people, my first euro, and a "so that's what all the fuss is about" moment. Nice to see the Kings & Things board again. Not something I'm that interested in playing, but definitely one of the first games that springs to mind to introduce people to the hobby.

item.name: Shadow Hunters
item.comment: Superb game. Only played once so far, but I am psyched to play this again. Psyched, I tell you!

item.name: Shadows over Camelot: The Card Game
item.comment: Well, I did not like this. Played with a large group of people I didn't know, might be better with friends? Has put me off even trying the full game, which I would hope is better.

item.name: Sherlock Holmes: The Card Game
item.comment: If you like Holmes and simple, Black Moria type card games (is that the game I'm thinking of? If not, then Chase the Ace, with a little more depth) then this is worth picking up. Nice production, and stands up pretty well to more modern fare. I keep trading/selling the copies I pick up, though, and without much regret.

item.name: Shiloh: April 1862
item.comment: I very much enjoyed this, my first and so far only block war game. I have a couple of ACW games at about this level of depth and (historical) strategic level - Wallace's Gettysburg, and the action dice driven Yankees & Rebels. Can never decide which one to play and end up playing something else. The system here is easy enough to pick up, works, and provides a challenge. Not sure whether there is a lot of depth of strategic options for players or a lot of replayability, but for what it is, it's a decent game. I do appreciate little mechanisms added to games for historical colour - in this case literally historical colour, as there's rules for a rebel company (brigade, whatever) dressed in blue uniforms at risk from friendly fire. Eventually I will find another gamer with about the same level of mild enthusiasm for the ACW as me to play these games with...

item.name: Shogun
item.comment: I very much liked Wallenstein, I like this more - for the theme and for the extra elements which are all better (at least than 1st ed Wally). The map more prone to turtling, or to a player benefitting inordinately from a passive neighbour? Well, maybe a tad, although really that is a general weakness of both games, and I suspect it is only ever so slightly exaggurated in this edition. Players who are well matched, and who either all play competitively or all be happy to do their own thing should not have any issues. I do understand the feeling that the theme (and the awesome battle tower) deserve more conflict dammit, but I don't know if that could ever be the same game, and this is a satisfying game. See Samurai & Katana for the theme with an appropriate level of bloodshed, negotiation and betrayal.

item.name: Small World
item.comment: Small World is fun, not exactly a game to rave about, but enjoyable enough.

item.name: Snowdonia
item.comment: I really liked this - there seems to be a variety of viable strategies, and its definitely a game where you need to pay attention to what other people are doing so that you can benefit from their choices. It's a little bit of a hodge-podge of mechanisms, but it definitely works.

item.name: The Sorcerer's Cave
item.comment: Fell in love with this game's slightly drab, classical aesthetic, which I still find very appealing today. A reissue should probably have smaller floor tiles and minis for the heroes, but no need to change anything else really. A solid dungeoncrawler, perhaps especially for solo play. Fun - frustrating when you keep falling down pit-traps and run out of tiles before you can work your way back to the exit, but no less fun for that.

item.name: Space Alert
item.comment: Extremely entertaining game, by far the most interesting implementation of co-operative mechanics that I have yet seen in a game. Component quality is top notch, and as the audio material can be downloaded as an app, the problems I've had owing to my crappy cd player are eliminated. Incoming threat!

item.name: Space Crusade
item.comment: Charity shop purchase - much better than I anticipated. Needs the odd house rule to balance things out maybe, though better than Heroquest for basic gameplay, which is Space Hulk-level solid. Quality of the figures is superb.

item.name: Space Empires: 4X
item.comment:
I really, really like Space Empires - I like all the old skool elements (the chits really resonate with me from the chits in various sf themed pocket games I played back in the 1980s), I enjoy the economic planning and like having the record sheet as a record of the game. Combat is just great.
But... I think I would ultimately have preferred it as a 2player only game, and as a block game. The chits are damn fiddly. That's not enough to turn me off the game - and if I found multiple opponenents willing to commit to a game then the possibility for more players is worth having.
The game really realizes its potential with the expansion. The solo options are solid if you are looking for that. And the system is open to house rules and modifications if you are that way inclined. I think it is the best empire-building space exploration and combat out there, and a welcome throwback to the very best 1980s game design ethics (which are pretty solid, and by no means rendered obsolete in the 21st century).

item.name: Space Hulk (third edition)
item.comment:
Hybrid set - 3rd edition box, chits and board pieces, 2nd edition genestealers, and a mix of c. 1993 marines and terminators.
Maybe I'm biased owing to having had to make do, but I believe I vastly prefer the earlier minis because I don't really go for diorama poses on game pieces.
Considering buying more board sections as they seem to be the cheapest component to turn up on ebay, with the most potential usefulness.
Hugely impressed by the quality of the board components. I never played the original: I imagine it was way out of my price range the first time around. I recall being deeply unimpressed by Citadel's early plastic miniatures, considering them a rip-off - not too sure now, as I generally find them much easier to paint (although they are undoubtedly a trifle light and brittle).
Everything I would want 40k to be - fast, simple and entertaining. Expecting that this one will see a lot of play over the years.

item.name: Spartacus: A Game of Blood & Treachery
item.comment: This is a highly enjoyable game. It is certainly flawed - hoarding VP-boosting cards seems to be a very effective strategy that can hand a player a win seemingly out of nowhere, and game-end can be anti-climatic. But the scheming and the excitement over the gladiator fights are very enjoyable. I think it would ultimately benefit from some well-thought-out house rules, and some slightly more interesting betting options... But this is a good 'un - amazing quality for a TV-themed, low-priced game.

item.name: Specter Ops
item.comment: Fun enough, not spectacularly different from other hunt-the-fugitive games, design a bit retro.

item.name: Spyrium
item.comment: A neat game. Would personally preferred it just themed on Coal rather than the silly steam punk trappings (or to have more of an interesting injection of genre flavour). But a decent engine-building game in a small package.

item.name: Squad Leader
item.comment: I've come to this after Combat Commander. As a solitaire game, I really enjoy it. Tottering stacks of counters in small hexes can be tough to handle, though - what do old grogs use?

item.name: Star Realms
item.comment: Started out playing it on a tablet, which my son (age 7) really enjoyed - so picked up a copy at the UK Games Expo, and the physical game is going down even better. I enjoy this, he loves it - and he beats me a lot. Plenty of luck in the draw, but what I really like over Ascension (to which it owes an awful lot in design terms) is that cards aren't worth points themselves - so there's no disincentive to trim your deck. Can't argue with the price, or the convenience - wish more games followed the example for packaging and pricing.

item.name: Star Trek III
item.comment: Must dig this one out again. I seem to remember particularly enjoying the tribbles/trading game ; the Kobayashi Maru may now be somewhat overly-complicated for what it can offer compared to, say, a computer game. Not sure I ever played the Sherwood game, owing to the theme. [Edit after a few plays] The trading game could be reworked as a two player, could also be reworked to be playable - mechanics are fun but maddening. Sherwood Syndrome quite engaging, but too difficult playing by the rules as printed. Couldn't be bothered to set up Kobayashi Maru.
item.conditiontext: Complete, used. Handy tray thoughtfully included by West End Games means that all the pieces are almost certainly there

item.name: Star Wars: Imperial Assault
item.comment: Campaign game: Definitely better than Descent 2 - the adventures feel much more substantial, though they also have a weird truncated feel with how the scenario stops as soon as objectives are achieved, and it feels very game-y in those last turns in particular ("Oh if we just do this and this, we can ignore those guys attacking us from all sides, and should win easy"). Seems much easier for the rebels, but maybe it should be - at least does not have the no-brainer spawn the best monster and block strategy for the overlord. The miniatures are a delight; character development is fun. An impressive amount in the box. Don't like the Imperial Walkers owing to the change of scale, which is annoying.

item.name: StarCraft: The Board Game
item.comment:
Lots that I really love about this game, but everyone seems to balk at the play length. Combat with it's deck-building, second-guessing, rewarding agression (somewhat tempered by the expansion?) is fun. Order placing ingenious. Bits are beautiful. Never played the computer game.
Even though about 17 of the aerial vehicles came with their stands broken off, I could not bring myself to avail FFG of their legendary customer service, and instead just manned-up and got out the sand-paper and super glue - the production on this was such a clear labour of love, that it seems churlish to put FFG at any additional expense. Great game! (Scaling seems good too, - plays well 2 player)

item.name: Steam
item.comment:
To date, only played 2 player with the Mrs, essentially as learning games. Managed to confuse track points and track tiles on our first game, yet still found it very engaging. 2nd game using base game and half the US board went well, 3rd we use the whole board , which was more to the wife's liking; 4th we tried base rules but with paying for upkeep of locomotives, on a full board. This didn't work so well, we seemed to run out of options after making our choices in the initial rounds.
Anyhoo, very nicely produced game, the Standard rules seem to have plenty if the cut-throat play that earlier incarnations are beloved for, the base game is, shockingly, a fun and accessible track building game.
Looking forward to playing with 3 or more players.

item.name: Steel Driver
item.comment: Really taken with this game - having now played Chicago Express but none of the other 13,000 similar train games, I'm unsure whether this would remain a favourite. Clever play though, and fast. The less than flashy components do have the worthy advantage (over CE) of being less distracting, easier to absorb information from. 'John Henry' cover has to be a bonus, even if it isn't reflected at all in the game play.

item.name: Stone Age
item.comment: If I played these games more often, I suspect that I may prefer Stone Age to Agricola or Puerto Rico, etc. Nice production values (esp compared to Ag & PR), maybe gameplay hasn't got all that much depth, but is fun to play.

item.name: Stratego
item.comment: Hate rating the classics. Stratego is a damn fine game, a real gem of the old rainy day family collections. Well worth thrifting into anyone's collections, should be a lot more licensed themes to compete with Monopoly on the super store shelves. Eg, a bad taste Al Quaida set.

item.name: Straw
item.comment: Very enjoyable. Gameplay kind of like Bucket King stripped down, with very nice card art; conveniently portable, surprised there's not more love on the geek. Edit : since buying, have to say I am really disappointed by the cheap matte cardstock. Feels like it would disintegrate after a few plays. Perhaps one reason there's not more love on the Geek.

item.name: A Study in Emerald
item.comment: An interesting game. From my one play, and from reading comments here, this does seem to be a game where the experience risks being affected by a player not getting it or refusing to get it or just not putting any effort in. But it's interesting all the same. The room for bluffing and twisted negotiations is an interesting aspect, and it works very well as a hidden loyalties game for 3 (haven't tried it with more yet). I like the art and the production values all round - some card scould have done with more text more clearly explaining their uses and limitations. Needs explaining well, needs patience and concentration - I think there's the depth here to reward that. Ankh-Morpork is more elegant and accessible, but so far this looks much more interesting (although it would be less likely to hit the table in my house).

item.name: A Study in Emerald (second edition)
item.comment: So... this was re-jigged to keep the Kickstarter exclusive, or what? I'm torn - it's more straightforward, more playable for a numbe rof reasons (easier to explain, easier to decide what to do) - but I think that it's less compelling as a result, though not as disappointing as I feared. Does that make sense?

item.name: Suburbia
item.comment: Would happily play this, but didn't find any great appeal.

item.name: Superpower
item.comment: Okay, I confused this with Supremacy. It looks to be incredibly dull and tedious to play. Tried to set it up, tried to read through the rules. Found it difficult to keep my eyes open. I'm going to take a chance and grade it a 1 without test-running it.

item.name: T.I.M.E Stories
item.comment: A first class mystery/puzzle solving game - or perhaps just a first class mystery puzzle. Bold design choice to have only one game in the box! The justification for the extremely limited replay is to play this in a group - maybe chip in to buy it? - then sell it on perhaps.

item.name: Tales of the Arabian Nights
