item.comment: The Z-Man edition is lush, lavishly produced, with thick, glossy tiles and weighs about a ton. As a devotee of programmed adventures, I love the design and concept, which is also very true to the source material. But the whole thing feels a little more like an archaic curiosity than a game. In the end I was able to sell it without too many pangs. Would happily sit down for a game, but I don't need it weighing down my shelves.

item.name: Talisman
item.comment: Classic game, good family fun. Best with first two expansions, less a couple of over-powered cards and characters. Crazy prices on ebay may eventually go down as the FFG copy establishes itself as THE edition. Think I gave my copy away when I thought I'd grown out of it.

item.name: Talisman (fourth edition)
item.comment:
Nice dice and coins in this edition, slightly pointlessly bigger board (the inner region is especially a waste of space - the obvious place to dump your adventure card stack, suspiciously large enough to fit a whole extra board...).
I much prefer the old Gary Chalk and John Blanche art, but the new stuff is nicely done (notably inferior to Runebound artwork).
Nothing done to address the old balance issues to prevent the game becoming 'Gnomequest'. Only innovation being allowed to collect Craft points - which now creates a new balance issue of craft being too easy to boost.
FFG's tweaks seem to be a bit more thought through, and now there is a hope of decent expansions, maybe some life will be breathed into this fondly remembered game.
item.conditiontext: Played but good condition - will consider a trade for 2e plus the Adventure and/or the Expansion in reasonable condition, or maybe Descent or something. Come on people, this edition has 6 dice with TALISMANS printed on and 'real' gold pieces!

item.name: Talisman (third edition)
item.comment: Played this once when a friend bought it and all the expansions for a few quid from The Works in Nottingham. Hated the art and Warhammer theme, but was very impressed that this was an edition where the expansions actually work together and make a fuller, epic game, rather than a colourful mess. Ugly as hell, though, especially the character cards.

item.name: Tanto Cuore
item.comment: Theme aside, this is too similar to Dominion for me. The theme is silly, but relatively harmless.

item.name: Tash-Kalar: Arena of Legends
item.comment: Too much like hard work for me.

item.name: Taxi!
item.comment: One of the better of the old Waddingtons games - definitely still playable.

item.name: Terra Mystica
item.comment: I probably haven't played this enough for a final verdict. It did seem just a little too dry long: as a beginner it's hard to do anything, so there's a feel of plodding along, that may or may not vanish with repeat plays. I would suggest Hansa Teutonica or Trajan instead.

item.name: Thebes
item.comment:
Fun, young-person-friendly game. In spite of lacking much in the way of real strategic depth, the time management mechanic and the (thematic) fun of the chance-laden artefact draws combine to make play engaging.
I think this is a neat combination of euro and AT sensibility : the theme is great, and although chance will play a big part in determining the winner, decisions feel real and meaningful throughout the game.
Furthermore, if you're in any way a 'fan' of 19th century cultural imperialism, well, this game really hits the spot.
Should be sold in museums everywhere instead of the lame 'roll and move' themed games they always carry in the gift shops - except then it would have to be called "The Crazy Fun Treasure Quest Game!"
Very nice components (archaeological drawbags and Indymeeples) and very nicely priced too. Rulebook could be a bit clearer on certain points, although after a play and a re-read it's all pretty much common sense.

item.name: Through the Ages: A Story of Civilization
item.comment: Sublime, intense, utterly immersing. Best with two or three, beat-downs can become unremitting and painful - going for a non-military strategy is a bold step, that must only be taken if you are prepared to be punished for it. It took me 6 years between first playing this game (and being absolutely blown away by it) and actually getting my own copy - the arrival of a new edition making this classic finally obtainable to incurable skinflints like myself.

item.name: Through the Desert
item.comment: The one game I played three players tied and the fourth won by one point. Is this usual? Anyway,thumbs up to all camel-themed games (perhaps replace the plastic with Oasis' lovely wooden cameeples)

item.name: Thunder Alley
item.comment: Great GMT production, but not sure if I really appreciate this.

item.name: Tichu
item.comment: Moved onto this after getting Haggis. It's a good game. I would repeat my comment that it leaves me feeling a little bit guilty for not knowing more traditional card games.

item.name: Ticket to Ride
item.comment: Has the virtue of simplicity and quick set-up time. Surprised I haven't seen a lot of people moaning about the need to buy the 1910 expansion to make it really playable. Have Days of Wonder fixed this in later editions?

item.name: Ticket to Ride: Europe
item.comment: The missus and my first game at the Liverpool Lions boardgaming club and a very enjoyable welcome to the hobby. Mrs F plays this obsessively online, I like it, but generally prefer to play something else. Prefer the variety of strategies to the original, but it definitely misses out on some of the elegant simplicity. Also, the stations make the game a lot harsher on beginners, and favour knowing the ticket deck. Edit (Oct 2010): My opinion has mellowed, and I find I generally enjoy TTR:E, 2 players or more. My previous thought that stations are "harsh" on beginners may have been influenced by the game I played being a very cut-throat 6-player bash. Now I have played Big Cities from 1912 I really want to get the expansion

item.name: Ticket to Ride: Märklin
item.comment: The edition we eventually bought, to satisfy my wife's love of the game and balance my own slight indifference. I like the fact that this edition comes with standard sized cards, the choice between long and short tickets, and the little passenger figures are cool : passenger mechanic adds variety to the game, is fairer to new players than stations, and of course can just be left out if you want to play the vanilla game and reward the longest track instead. Main disadvantage, when playing with passengers, is setting up time (extra 5-10 minutes) and general fiddliness of the goods markers.

item.name: Time of Soccer
item.comment: The authentic Football Manager experience, in cardboard form. Requires players to be sharp in calculating and recalculating their attack and defence scores, though this can (and really should) be done during the down time of other players' turns. I think I would have prefered a simple draft rather than the driving around the city sub game, but that does its own job of making getting the squad you want a challenge.

item.name: Tinners' Trail
item.comment: Really solid, maybe the epitome of Wallace's lighter euros?

item.name: Titan
item.comment: I am currently fascinated by Titan after picking up a copy of the Avalon Hill edition. 2 player is great - I would dearly love to play a 6 player game, but how to justify the downtime and the ruthlessness of the player elimination? I wouldn't mind it personally (I think) because as I say I find the game fascinating, but am unsure of the chances of finding 5 like-minded deviants.

item.name: To Court the King
item.comment: Bizarrely over-the-top and impractical production (some strange choices of symbol and the important stuff is small and hard to read), but this is an intriguing addition to the Yahtzee family.

item.name: Top Race
item.comment:
I don't love Top Race, but I do like it. The thing is that I traded away Ave Caesar after getting TR, feeling that TR does everything AC does and more, which is true BUT
it is just more fun sending chariots around the track and hailing Caesar.
The game system here is cleverer than Ave Caesar, more of a game to get your teeth into and better able to scale (eg it plays perfectly well with 2) but for some reason I miss the roar of the crowd in the collosseum...

item.name: Trajan
item.comment:
Played this late in the evening at UK Games Expo, with a fried brain and sat with the board upside-down to me. As I actually did very well, I thought this was a very satisfying and well-designed game.
The mancala is interesting - it drives your play and there are ways it can be exploited, ways it can trip you up. It ties in to three elements of the game - how you choose what action to take, whether you get a bonus tile (if available) for the action you take, and how much you push the game clock on. Similar sorts of choices, decisions and benefits to rondel systems. At the moment |I'm finding the 'push the game clock' element to be of most tactical significance - forcing the early end of a turn can deprive your opponent of points, whilst you make sure to score easy quick points early on. It has the potential to be baffling or induce AP, but I found it pretty intuitive to use.
Components-wise the game is a pleasing package. There is a bit of set up and tear down involved owing to the million and one pieces, manageable in about ten minutes each way.
The game (in my playing experience) it feels closest to is Village - multiple ways to score, manipulation of time and game length. Trajan is less novel and somewhat less interactive, but it feels as though there may be more to explore in the range of tactical options.

item.name: Trippples
item.comment: Not a bad game, worth picking up for a pound or so from a charity shop.

item.name: Trivial Pursuit
item.comment: Still the king of trivia games, but maybe that isn't saying much, post internet. Still a great nostalgia trip to play the original edition once every 5 or 10 years. Top tip - guess Daley Thompson or Duran Duran for any question you don't know the answer to.

item.name: Tsuro
item.comment: Lovely production. Proper filler - with no-mercy player elimination! Great with all ages.

item.name: Twilight Struggle
item.comment: I find the subject matter a big draw, and I am a sucker for the production of the deluxe edition, which is very shallow of me. Gameplay is tense and engaging. The main drawback of the game is that the players need to have about the same level of knowledge of the cards for the contest to be fair; but tht is where the long-term strengths of the game appear to lie, in the depth of strategy as the potential of card and board play are explored. Playing out the last century's struggles of the Long War that have shaped this one is an engaging way to spend an hour or two, especially with a glass of single malt whiskey to hand. May not be the greatest game of all time, but it does deserve its spot in the top ten. Edit: It occurs to me from my misspelling whisky above that the US player really needs to be drinking Bourbon and the USSR player a good vodka.

item.name: Tycoon
item.comment: About as stripped down as a majorities/investment game can be, with an utterly brutal loans sytem thrown in to teach a cruel, harsh economic lesson to the unsuspecting family gamer.

item.name: Unexpected Treasures
item.comment: This isn't a deep game by any means and may play slightly long for what it is, but I really like Unexpected Treasures. I enjoy the theme of scavenging scrap from the junk yard to sell or "furnish your own home." I like the blind bidding, the burglary shenanigans, the tie breaking mechanism and just love the simple but pleasing integration of theme in this game.

item.name: Vikings
item.comment: Enjoyable tile-placement game, fun auction mechanic and nicely produced. People who don't get how the theme of building up little communities relates to vikings need to read more history. A childhood of summers visiting the museums of Northumbria larned me better!

item.name: Villa Paletti
item.comment: Have a lot of fun playing this with my kids - they're age 2 to 6. More as an activity than a game as such, but the turn-taking and the fact that we work together doing it are good game-playing characteristics that Villa Paletti develops. Very good component quality.

item.name: Village
item.comment: Early impression: that the game is nice enough, but a little bit lacking in a certain spark, probably owing to the abundance of possible actions that have very close net end results. The test will come with replayability. After 4 plays - racing to score and kill off your family, balancing when to take the developing actions (growing family, making goods) and when to reap... We're finding the 2 player game to be fast (30 - 45 minutes - currently lasting about 3 full rounds) and so far promising sufficient variability - what actions represent the best opportunity will vary depending on the mix of cubes available and customers on the market. There's something fun about filling the grave slots (and interesting that that's just about the only blocking move available), and controlling when to kill the game is absolutely key.

item.name: Wallamoppi
item.comment: Beautiful components, gameplay a little bit so-so.

item.name: Wallenstein (first edition)
item.comment:
Very satisfying game. The mechanic of choosing your orders before resolving them is becoming a strong favourite of mine, and is extremely well implemented here.
And how could anyone not love the Tower of Destiny?

item.name: War of the Ring (first edition)
item.comment:
Bought this to have a crack at painting the miniatures. Once finished, plunged in with the standard game, which went down surprisingly well with the missus. Beautifully produced game, clever and engaging mechanics. Knowledge of Middle-Earth geography and LOTR is very helpful, especially as map board is difficult to read once loaded with miniatures, but I didn't find the issues so bad as others. Took about 5 hours for our first game - had no idea how much time had passed. Exceeded expectations.
Shame about the lack of Gollum, Gandalf the White and Aragorn miniatures. Look forward to acquiring the expansion, hope the makers think up some other expansions or variations for the future. In many ways the core mechanics seem very similar to Blue Vs Gray - so a Civil War game or other historical conflict would be nice. This would surely be the mechanics and production values best suited to an epic Genghis Khan game!
I am honestly not obsessed with LOTR, but too many of the games are just so damned good.
Edit: upped rating to 10, which it is impossible to deny this game.
item.wantpartslist: One dwarven regular wanted - dammit. Will pay cash money! Edit: Replaced by FFG's superlative customer service - many thanks, Thaadd>

item.name: War on Terror
item.comment: After first play: (6 players) Set up a game of this with some trepidation, but it did not disappoint. Most players had studied the rules a bit, so were reasonably well prepared for play. Wonderful the game changes through play, and surprising the way a real geo-political feeling somehow emerges. Not a million miles in feel from Imperial 2030, although by way of very very different mechanics. Also hilarious. Might get tiring to play too often, but I'd be very happy to play this again. In spite of it being very tight (and me being the axis of evil for nearly an hour) I wore the balaclava fully. Hard core!

item.name: WarCraft: The Board Game
item.comment:
As with Starcraft, I am playing this ignorant of the computer game, but as with that game's order mechanic, there is something that feels 'real-time strategy' about the choice of commands in this game.
I very much like the wooden squirrels, shopping trolleys and Cartmans, and would enjoy playing this more often.
The expansion seems to be a must, certainly adds depth without overcomplicating things.

item.name: The Warlock of Firetop Mountain
item.comment: For the occasional piece of light hearted fun, this game hits the spot especially for those with fond memories of Fighting Fantasy gamebooks.
item.conditiontext: This is in well-worn condition, backs of a lot of the chits and maze cards so worn that they are easily identified (would need replacement backs printing, I guess). None of the original minis. Would happily trade for something in similar condition :)

item.name: Warrior Knights
item.comment:
Have long loved this game - played many games as a kid, quite possibly without ever finishing one. Tricked my wife into a 2 player game and to my surprise she loved it - turned out this may have had more to do with the continuous runs of bad luck I had in that game, as she was infinitely less thrilled when the dice turned against her on a seceond play.
The assembly voting mechanic for two players works surprisingly well, and keeps this a very interesting game. For modern gamers, the main problem with Warrior Knights is the randomness - but this is of course built into the game to reflect the chaotic uncertainty of the period - that an army may be decimated by plague on the brink of success. It makes a win extremely difficult to predict, but likewise makes the game more about the experience of playing than winning.
The other elements of the game seem very familiar when looking at the likes Puerto Rico and even Settlers - and for my money, Warrior Knights did this far better in terms of entertainment and, well, beauty of play. No pasted on themes here!

item.name: Warrior Knights
item.comment:
An interesting game. To contrast with the original: biggest difference is that although assemblies are important, it is not even a clear case for them being more important than any one other element - certainly they are not the single most important aspect of the game. And this is kind of disappointing, if unavoidable, and a little strange as so much of the game is familiar. The way that luck is handled - can be mitigated, is dice-less - is interesting. There is still plenty of the uncertainty, but it is far less likely that a random card draw or dice roll will suddenly reverse or finish the game. Money is less important, which was unexpected (eg, there is not a true auction for mercenaries).
Combat is remarkably similar, but definitely one aspect that is more interesting in how it is handled - the drawing of cards, rather than the mere rolling of dice and consulting a result chart.This effects being more manageable whilst yet less predictable. Fate tokens, and the assigning of good and bad cards by the bishop, are the feature that I find most unappealing, they seem to spoil the theme, but, dammit, gamwise they work pretty well.
The action selection and planning are a whole new game, and the long and short is that they are a very good implementation of this type of mechanic.
Verdict: I'd like to think that I would still prefer the original, although it may probably turn out that I actually enjoy this version more. I miss the rhythym of the original, and the fact that Warrior Knights 1.1 was all about the assembly - remember the drama of whether or not a Baron attended. But this was definitely engaging and enjoyable.

item.name: Wars of the Roses: Lancaster vs. York
item.comment:
Rated after 2 4-player and 2 2-player games.
So it's an area control euro 'disguised' as a historical wargame. Works for me. The disguise is well effected, without compromising the game's very clear and straight forward euro roots. Simultaneous planning makes for plenty of tension, and so far each game has played out very differently.
Particularly like the way factions work in 4 player - you can never quite trust your 'ally', but your interests will often be thrown together.
As for the 'glorified rock-paper-scissors'criticism - well, out-thinking your opponents and making calculated guesses is critical, and creates uncertainty without the randomness of dice rolling. A clever, elegant design. With a minimum of rules too, the game should be very accessible to people without much board-gaming experience.
Top-notch components, as one comes to expect from Z-man.
Curious choice for cover art, though. I get that the design is Australian, but Ayers Rock seems an unusual backdrop for mediaeval England.

item.name: Wealth of Nations
item.comment:
Because I did vastly better at my second game having learnt valuable lessons from my first, I can say that I like this. It appears that the game is prone to runaway leaders, but interestingly our first game was dominated by bankers, whereas in the second they barely paid back the setup investment. If players or indeed a single player do not pay attention to what others are doing and where the demand is in the economy, the sitaution can be ruthlessly exploited by others.
On the whole I think I would prefer to play some other economic game, but this has its merits. Doubt it would be improved by takeovers and conflict.

item.name: Wings of War: The Dawn of World War II
item.comment: Beautifully produced game, very impressive what comes in the box - greAt value for money. Elegant, fun mechanics. Sadly Mrs S really isn't taken with this or I would rush to buy and play all the time.

item.name: Witch's Brew
item.comment: Definitely a very fun but slightly longish filler game. What I would like to get family or friends who enjoy Citadels to move on to, although probably a tad over-complicated for most ungamey people.

item.name: Wordigo
item.comment: Gameplay an enjoyable fusion of Boggle and Scrabble. Completing your first level four board with seconds to spare is a thrill : then finding that your first word ('GIB') is in your imagination rather than your dictionary, so all those bonus points are suddenly wiped out... Entertaining, and with a well-engineered system to allow players of all skill/vocabulary levels to compete - although as previously noted, player interaction (as with Boggle) isn't really part of play. Nice components, too, although the drawstring bags in my edition are inexplicably labelled "Sudoku" rather than "Wordigo."

item.name: Yahtzee
item.comment: Play this all the time w Mrs Schkff (her choice, but I don't mind it). Don't think I've ever managed to score 3 or more Yahtzees in a game, in spite of what feels like thousands of games played over the years.

item.name: Yahtzee Deluxe Poker
item.comment: A thoroughly enjoyable Yahtzee-based bidding and betting game.

item.name: Yardmaster
item.comment: It's silly, but something about the high quality of the graphic design in contrast to the simplicity of game play put me off. Many other set-collecting games I'd rather play, nothing to set this apart for me - though full marks for the very sturdy, sensibly-sized box.

item.name: Yedo
item.comment:
At its best, playing Yedo is an intense experience, richly thematic as you struggle to bring your clan to ascendency through nefarious plots and double dealing. The game mechanisms that implement this are splendidly crafted - there's randomness through shuffled cards and events - but ways to counter that randomness and even to make it work for you (through 'foresight' actions). Spectacular gains and catch ups are possible - or you might get out front and stay out front, blocking your rivals at every step, consolidating your power base. Or, and this might be considered Yedo at its worst unless you have a particularly deep strain of masochism, the game can be a long sequence of frustrations at every turn, making little or no progress, every possible event that could screw things up just that little bit further getting drawn, every lucky break that could put your opponents ahead working out for them. I don't believe that this is a flaw in the game. When I've had a truly horrible game (which pretty much sums up 3 games out of 8 played so far) the down turn in my luck was mostly down to a crucial poor decision on my part - a great goal discarded, an impossible mission hung onto for too long, letting an opponent in two player get the third and final geisha in the auctions (NB - do NOT let your opponent in a 2p game get the third and final geisha - do you really need to be told this?)... And only one of those three games was actually mostly a horrible experience to play. The possibility of total and utter ignominous defeat makes the glorious victories possible all the sweeter.
Comparisons: Superficially like Waterdeep because you are sending out workers and completing missions for veeps. The game which it most seems to resemble to me though is Mechanisburgo - another rich, intense and thematic WP. Significantly, though, Yedo has simple and intuitive rules, Mechanisburgo does not. The thematic depth should appeal to players who hate dry euroism, but with the chaos being quite manageable if you play it that way, the game should also appeal to players who enjoy a thoughtful, dynamic system that creates efficiency puzzles to solve.
Play time: Two player takes 1 hour, with 3 - 5 the play time creeps up, maybe maxing out at 2 1/2 hours with 5 players who like to consider their choices carefully. For me 2 1/2 hours is by no means too long to be playing one game, and indeed the experience of playing Yedo is comparable to those games which usually take 3-5 hours to play - so I don't hold with the 'too long' criticisms.
Random nastiness: As noted, through using foresight actions, the randomness is all manageable I just don't see it as a fault at all. It creates an environment of risk - in which you may take chances or proceed with caution as you prefer. There are some great "Gah!" moments in this game.
Take thatiness/blockinginess: A lot of opportunities to cause people hurt and to block people's plans. Again, I think the balance is about right. With 2 players it seems nastier because if you can get ahead then you can probably afford to just concentrate on stymying your opponent. Woe betide you if they manage to find a way through, though. At times then the game can feature INTENSE conflict and competition, but this tends to be periodic, generally not completely determining the outcome of a game (plenty of steps you can take, action cards you can arm yourself with to defend yourself against the ill-intentions of others) - the fact that it can sometimes be critical adds to the frisson of excitement that runs through the game - am I going to get royally screwed before (or worse just after) I get this game-clinching mission completed?

item.name: Yomi
item.comment:
Complete First Edition: I was always rubbish at playing Street Fighter, but I enjoyed watching my mates slug it out. Yomi translates SF to a form that I can actually play, and I so far am finding it delightful.
There's a lot that's impressive about the game. I love games that are simple to explain - though that means that the nuances in Yomi can translate as fiddliness - nonetheless, it should only take a quick bout or two for most people to pick the thing up - and the fact that it can be explained as Rock, Paper, Scissors - draw a card and play (then the nuances gone into as the game unfolds) is wonderful - though clearly a lot of BGGers have baggae associated to RPS (see most negative comments on this game for a sample). You can ignore RPS during play - you don't have to think about out-guessing your opponent - just try to make good moves with the cards you have. Sometimes you'll hit, and sometimes you'll be hit. Studies on RPS show that guessing randomly is the most effective strategy in that game. That simply ain't so with Yomi - because the value of any given card in any given situation is going to differ - with some characters a certain move will always be more likely, or more or less effective. It's very notable that the (consistently) top ranking players of Yomi are also poker professionals. Bluffing and reading bluffs are not the principal skills in professional poker - understanding the probabilities of any given card or play are much more significant.
Anyhow, I like that you can take this game seriously and learn the decks and better plays, or you can just get into the fight and start punching and blocking as the whim takes you, or you can try get in your opponent's head and frustrate the heck out of them - any of which approaches to the game seems to be viable. Huge variability from the ten characters and corresponding match ups, and remarkable balance for the significantly differing powers, strengths and weaknesses.
The designer's forthright and widely disemminated opinions clearly rub some up the wrong way. I'll take it as eccentricity. The design is unquestionably solid, and I for one appreciate that the game was designed as a whole, in a non-CCG, non-LCG model. Just like buying a cartridge of Street Fighter. I'll treat 2nd edition like SF II, and I guess if I get bored of 1st Edition some day, try and hunt it down. I'll happily try out someone else's 2nd edition, but I'm happy to stick with 1st for myself until I am finished with it.

item.name: Yomi: Round 2
item.comment: Great, but as I have Round 1, I'm not bothered about getting Round 2. Tempted seeing a box of 4 decks for £10, which is great value, but I'm happy with the first edition.

item.name: Zombicide
item.comment: I found Zombicide to be more fun than I expected, a decent design. The only rule that seemed to gamey and disappointing is the one about automatically shooting compadres, but the look and feel of the game is perfect for the theme.
